reviewText: All I have to say is Liam sets a new standard once again. Don't miss this action-packed film. This is one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. not too long, not too short....just right.

Retired CIA agent, Bryan (Liam Neeson) must call on all of his past job skills when his teenaged daughter (Maggie Grace) and her friend are kidnapped by people traffickers, while on vacation in France.

I really enjoyed "Taken". It is a really dumb film with "violence solves everything" as its central message (and the incongruously heavy themes of drugs, prostitution and slavery, but lets not dwell on those), but in spite of these things (or perhaps because of them), it was exciting, fast-moving and a really fun movie to watch. Although starting to look a bit on the old side, Neeson does a commendable job as a former spy called back into action and surprisingly he makes this piece of far-fetched fluff seem somewhat believable...somewhat.

The script of "Taken" is co-written by Luc Besson, who is among my favourite writers, and although not of the calibre of "Leon - The Professional", or even "Taxi",  Besson is still a better writer than most action film writers out there and as a results, this film is well worth your time and money.

If you liked the Bourne movies (especially 2 and 3), then you'll enjoy Taken... I personally found it more involving. In summary, a great and believable action thriller, with a superb performance by Liam Neeson.

This movie took me back to Neeson in the original Darkman movie. Barely controlled murderous anger in a hangdog face.  To find his daughter who has been Taken, Neeson does not back down. Leaving a trail of dead and broken bodies across Paris whether it be cop or criminal.  Non-stop action from start to finish. This one is a keeper.

(4.5 stars) This movie was a bit like watching James Bond destroy the bad guys.  It's over-the-top all around.  An action movie and a violent movie.  But like my title says, it was intense and thrilling.  How Neeson's character got out of France I don't know.  Not after all the damage he caused, and people he killed or injured.  And because it's squeezed into 90 minutes it really packs a punch.  I didn't realize this movie was the first of a trilogy (as of this writing).  I am curious about the other two movies having just watched this one.  I'd give it five stars except that it all seems so unlikely.  Anyhow, this movie is recommended provided you don't mind the over-the-top violence.

I love Liam Neeson but this is definitely not his best work.  Well, he did the best he could with what he had to work with. The characters are so shallow and clich that I almost stopped watching it in the middle.  Then at least the action  picked  up, and I was able to make it through the rest of the movie.  Therefore, I gave it two stars instead of one.  Also it really asks you to suspend a lot of disbelief.
Aside  from the usual man pretending to be super hero and defying all odds , he committed multiple crimes on his quest to save his daughter and some of them were against innocent people and there was no mention whatsoever of him taking any responsibility for that.
And if you have any respect for women whatsoever, I don't see how you can appreciate their portrayal in this movie.  The mom is a coldhearted B, the friend is  a flirt who apparently got what she deserved when she ended up dead  and the daughter is a nave, self-centered virgin who draws  over a half million dollars in a bidding war  at the "prostitute/slave" auction.  But of course daddy saves her before she loses her purity. Don't waste your money buying a copy. Check it out from the library (like I did).  Peter Sagal got it right when he said it's a fantasy film for divorced dads.  In fact I don't even feel comfortable repeating what he said about the film. Soooo disappointing.

Taken is one of the most morally bankrupt films ever made for mainstream American audiences. The "hero" at it's center is constantly making repulsive choices. Or rather doing nothing when the right thing would be pretty damn easy. Time after time he breezes right by dozens of girls who are living the life of a sex slave, the awful fate he wants to save his daughter from.

After killing a bunch of bad guys at a construction site, Neeson just drives off. Doesn't try to rescue any of the girls being held there. No offer to drive anyone to a police station. Won't even offer them a few bucks for the bus.

At one point Neeson finds the body of his daughter's best friend. Does he make any attempt to send her back to her parents? Of course not. In the sick morality of this film, the best friend deserved to die because how dare she want to go the Europe? How dare she want to talk to European boys?

At the climax, a creepy sheik has the daughter and two other girls on his yacht. Neeson bursts in, kills the baddies and daddy and daughter are reunited. What of the other two girls? Who knows. We literally see them for about ten seconds and then never again. Even AFTER Neeson has what he wants, he won't life a finger to help someone else. He doesn't care, nor does the movie. And come to think of it, even the daughter doesn't say a word about helping the other girls.

I know there are people who will defend this by saying, "It's a dumb action movie," "Check yur brain at the door," "its not sposd to be real lol." If a plot is going to involve the very real world of sex slavery, there should be some attempt to treat the story and the characters (and the audience) with a shred of plausibility and a modicum of moral consideration.

TAKEN

I know what you are going to say but here it is anyway, thus far I have only watched the first film in this series even though I own all three. After seeing this one again recently on TV I have decided to finally go through all three. So I had to revisit this one in Blu-Ray form.

The story follows an ex CIA operative as he travels to France in order to find and save his daughter. He was on the phone with her when she was Taken and now he is using everything he knows to track her down and hunt down her captors. Human trafficking is something he has dealt with before in his line of work and knows what she could be in for as a sex slave sold on the black market.

This was a really good flick that kinda brought back that old school feel for me. A classic story full of mindless violence but violence with a purpose, it is his daughter after all. This is Liam at his best here as the style of the film fits him perfectly. Writers Luc Besson  and Robert Kamen who both gave us this series along with The Transporter series and films like Kiss of the Dragon and the classic The Fifth Element  wrote a really good story that director Pierre Morel [From Paris with Love] took and ran with. This thus far is my favorite in the series mainly because I have yet to watch the other two, I will fix that very soon.

"Taken" is a film that keeps you glued to the TV the entire time, the pace is so perfect. There were 3 films made (so far) and this first film is the best one. The others are worth seeing but this one is good for repeated viewings.

Liam Neeson plays a man (a former spy) with a "particular set of skills" that you don't want to mess with. His daughter is kidnapped while travelling to Paris, France and he sets out to get her back. We are bombarded with these "former spy" dark action heros in movies and most of these films have the same thin plots, are made very quickly, rely on lots of effects and just plainly suck! This film works very well. It's mostly hand to hand combat and Neeson is convincing in the role (although by the 3rd film he's starting to look too old).

If you like this film, also check out Neeson in "A Walk Among the Tombstones", which is similar and very good.

Taken is a movie that has received a huge Cult Following since its release in 2008 and has become one of Liam Neeson's most defining movies of his career and has earned him a reputation as one of the most beloved action movie stars of this generation. The story of Taken revolves around Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson), a Former CIA agent who's daughter, Kim (Maggie Grace), travels to Paris with a friend but are soon kidnapped by a group of Albanians. Bryan then travels to Paris and uses his set of skills to rescue his daughter before she is gone forever. There are a lot of things about Taken that makes it awesome: Liam Neeson, the story, the drama, the dialogue, and last but not least: the badass action scenes. The action scenes are so fun to sit through and just seeing Neeson's character fight his way through Paris to rescue his daughter is absolutely satisfying. One little flaw that the movie does have is that it is predictable. Other than that, Taken really is a fantastic action movie and if you haven't seen it, you are really missing out.

Taken is a French thriller starring Liam Neeson, Maggie Grace and Famke Janssen.

Bryan Mills is a former Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) operative who sets about tracking down his daughter after she is kidnapped by human traffickers while traveling in France. He sets on a frantic quest to rescue her after the young girl is abducted by slave traders in District B13.

This is film provides a lot of fun and entertainment as a predictable action thriller. It's got all the attributes of a pleasurable action thriller - excitement, some undeniably enjoyable scenes and the absence of what it needs to be more memorable and more substantial. Also,a viewer is introduced to a new side of Liam Neeson, one that is relentless and likes to hit criminals in the throat and he makes this action movie engaging. That is why this is one excellent film despite of being far from a masterpiece.

Taken is a well done action thriller starring Liam Neeson. When his daughter goes over to Paris, France with her friend Amanda to basically follow a rock band touring, he is very concerned knowing what kind of world we REALLY live in. After being virtually forced to signing a document giving his consent by his estranged wife played by Famke Jannsen, he gets the phone call he has been dreading. Both his daughter and her girlfriend have been kidnapped by Albanian thugs to be sold in the sexual slave trade in foreign 3rd world countries. Little do the Albanians know just what kind of man Bryan Mills IS. They find out one by one in a good movie that sheds light on just exactly what happens to quite a few women going overseas by themselves.
Special Features are ~
Theatrical and Extended Versions
Commentary by Director and writers
Black OPS Field Manual
Le Making of
Avant Premiere
Inside Action: Side by Side
Several Movie Trailers
DTS 5.1 HD sound

Oh dear - but this was bad - I am not sure it would have had to be - but the plot is predictable - early on you guess the daughter will get taken, the dad will save her, the bad guys cannot shoot straight and Liam Neeson will prevail against odds of 50:1 - the fact that Neeson passes himself off as a french political aide (speaking English) is probably lost on monolingual audiences, for the rest of us, you just go - hm dead giveaway - the REALLY bad guys are all Arabs and who cannot shoot straight and apparently prefer to buy American girls - oh and Neesons daughter's acting in the movie is abysmal and as she is also not particularly attractive the plot of her being sold off for a lot of money is even less believable (probably because she is American?) - this isn't of course the point, but it would help make the movie more believable.  Loads of shots of women being abused, shots of emaciated women, drugs, and torture scenes, and a lot of illogical action - e.g. if Neeson is at the airport in France and has identified the spotter - why doesn't he trail him, watch the next victim and then catch the bad guys when they show up to abduct her - I guess because that would be the logical thing to do AND because of course then the movie would only take 20 minutes. I love action movies - most movies with Jason Statham in them, or Leon - but this one, oh dear..

"You have to see this movie!"

Those are the words impressed upon me a while back when, during a conversation about favorite films, I told a friend that I hadn't seen Taken yet. After being informed that this was one of the best movies since Braveheart, I was ordered to watch Taken lest I deprive myself of something as vital as air. Now, having seen Taken to see if was worth that hype, I realize I shouldn't have held my breath.

Liam Neeson plays a retired spy on the hunt for his somewhat-estranged teenage daughter who has been abducted in France by sex traffickers, and as I watched I quickly suspected that this was a script originally intended for Harrison Ford. The movie just had that Harrison Ford vibe, you know what I mean? A dutiful father is placed in a life-threatening situation in which he must go to extreme measures to protect his family; it's the kind of movie Ford--let's face it--is known for. But, I guess he was too busy filming that terrible Indiana Jones sequel to bother with this film, and so we get Neeson and his muddled American-ish accent.

There's not really a whole lot to say about the movie. The entire plot is preposterous and requires a fair amount of suspension of disbelief, which I can handle. I just wasn't expecting a movie that was designed less for someone of Liam Neeson's caliber than an action movie scrounged out of Sylvester Stallone's or Bruce Willis' remainder bin. Just think of Taken like this: It's what would happen if Jason Bourne got married, had a kid, then that kid got kidnapped.

It's a fun ninety minutes, don't get me wrong, but when I'm told this is the best movie since Braveheart--and that was a damned good movie, by the way--I expect a little more depth and subtext to the movie. Foolish on my part, I now realize. There are fights, chases, gun fights, more chases, and a couple of nice one-liners for Neeson. Famke Janssen appears early in the film as Neeson's ex-wife, playing the scornful wedge between father and daughter like there's no tomorrow, but her role is one of a precious few given any consideration in terms of character.

Rent it, nuke some popcorn, and enjoy. Just don't set the bar too high because Braveheart this is not.

After the movie, I thought it was okay.  After having had a day to think about it, I realize that it wasn't.  This is typical Hollywood formulaic crap, with characters that aren't developed at all (except for our protagonist) and a plot that's simply a rehash of every other rescue-the-girl-by-killing-every-bad-guy film ever made.  What bothers me the most, though, is the manipulation of the audience--if they can make the bad guys bad enough, then we as an audience aren't disturbed at all by Neeson murdering all of them in cold blood.  In fact, we cheer for him, and we're glad these "vermin" are wiped out.  Neeson is decent here, but none of the other actors have roles that challenge them at all, so there's no real other acting here.  And how convenient is it that his daughter's friend is dead when he finds her, so that he doesn't have to do anything to rescue her and possibly complicate the plot?  It's also incredibly convenient that the line holding the pipe that he's handcuffed to is loose, and convenient that terrorists with full automatic weapons are able to miss him at extremely close range. . . . it goes on and on.

Good movie! It's a unique spin on the action movie genre, which, as we all know, could use a good kick in a new direction. The fast-paced and somewhat realistic choreography on the fight scenes and sense of suspense driven by the intensely real father-daughter relationship made the plot easy and exciting to follow. The sharply written dialogue was of a much better caliber than most big-budget blockbusters, and had me and my old friends quoting it for a good while to come. While it wasn't the next Citizen Kane or anything, it was one of the better movies I've seen in recent years and was exactly what an actor like Liam Neeson deserved.

Tense, exciting, well done movie. Liam Neeson was perfect for the role of the father. I realized after it was over that I had not relaxed at all and even had a mild headache from being so tense the entire time.

THE FILM: TAKEN is a simple action movie about a family man with "a particular set of skills" that takes down a sex trafficking ring in order to rescue his daughter after she is kidnapped while on holiday in Paris. While this could have gone straight to the bargain bin, what really sells this movie is Liam Neeson, who brings a everyman quality to his role as Bryan Mills. The production values by Luc Besson and director Pierre Morel are also worth noting, with just enough emotional content to make the story relatable and a kinetic style that keeps things moving along at a good pace. Generally speaking everyone gives a decent performance, but I thought that Maggie Grace was miscast as she doesn't look the part of a 17-year-old girl, and her acting is questionable at best. Story-wise, I did appreciate that the movie took time to establish characters and relationships before heading off into more standard action thriller territory but, that being said, it only taps into the basest of human emotions and tendencies. Only someone devoid of empathy wouldn't understand the sticky situation that the characters are put into. Still, despite the rote nature of the setup it works, and the latter two-thirds of the movie rarely let up. As far as the action is concerned, it is well-shot for the most part. Pierre Morel shoots the close quarters combat up close, but the editing isn't so bad that you can't tell who's fighting who, and the geography and shot compositions are decent. If there's one complaint I have in this area is a nighttime car chase which was perhaps a bit too chaotically shot/edited. Overall, this is a decent time-passer that has enough story and thrills to keep you interested, and the running time is only about 90 minutes so it never overstays it's welcome.

THE EXTRAS: There is a decent amount of supplementary material presented here, chief of which are not one, but two commentaries for the extended version of the film. There is also a Black-Ops Field Manual picture-in-picture feature (also for the extended version) that highlights geographical locations and such while the movie is playing. Additionally, there are three featurettes which highlight different aspects of the production. The first of these is an 18-minute production featurette that has interviews with Liam Neeson, Maggie Grace and Pierre Morel. What can be taken from this is that Liam Neeson really enjoyed himself, Maggie Grace enjoyed getting to work with Liam Neeson and the director went into this project with slightly higher ambitions than just making an action film. You also get to see how hands on the director was, given his history as a camera operator and director of photography for Luc Besson (who co-wrote and produced this). After this, there is a 5-minute featurette with premiere footage, and 11 minutes of side-by-side comparisons of several scenes in the film with behind-the-scenes footage of same. Overall, I'd say there is a decent amount of supplementary material that should satisfy fans who go for that sort of thing.

OVERALL: It may not be thought-provoking or engaging on anything but a visceral level, but it's effective at what it sets out to do. Not only that, but cinephiles are rewarded with a handsome set of bonus features. Recommended for action junkies and Liam Neeson fans.

Nearly 2.5 million people are taken against their will every year and sold into the $32 billion sex trade industry. Its unfortunate that none of those people have Bryan Mills as their father. While my own knowledge of human trafficking is limited, it is clear that Taken does a poor job of reifying that topic. The storyline is unconvincing and unrealistic which makes it hard to appreciate what the film is trying to accomplish. The performance of Liam Neeson is the exception, and his acting is what makes the film watchable.
 Ex-CIA agent Bryan Mills, (Liam Neeson) has moved to California to be closer to his high school aged daughter Kim (Maggie Grace). Kim makes plans to travel to Europe for summer break. Upon arriving in Paris, Kim and her friend Amanda are kidnapped by Albanian gangsters to be sold into the sex trade. Mills travels to Europe to track down Kim with the help of his CIA connections.
 Even though Mills was in the CIA, this film embellishes the power and intelligence of the organization. If this film was even a close representation to what the real CIA is like, the U.S. would never have been involved in a war on terrorism. In Taken, Mills friends in the CIA are able to take a recording of the suspected captor and analyze to find out that the persons name is Marko, a suspected Albanian gangster operating in human trafficking. While Im sure this sort of voice recognition technology exists, it seems all but realistic in that given situation. There is a sequence in the film where Mills has been captured and is about to be executed. He manages to rip the pipe out of the ceiling, from which he is attached, and kill all of the armed men in the room. This provided for a great action scene but not one that had any hint of realism to say the least. These unrealistic elements of the film made it seem much like an action movie instead of a thriller because of the countless number of times that Mills is able to miraculously cheat death.
 Some scenes in the film are so unrealistic that they are actually humorous to watch. The fact that the kidnapping of Kim and Amanda takes place in Paris during broad daylight stood out as one of the most unrealistic scenes in the film. First off, why would anyone choose broad daylight to kidnap someone? How was a small team of criminals able to kidnap Kim and Amanda from their posh Paris penthouse without being seen? And wouldnt people living in the apartment be able to hear the screams of teenage girls? I think if the film had taken a more realistic approach to how these kidnappings occur then that would have made it much more horrifying.
 Thank goodness for Liam Neeson, the saving grace for this film. Neeson played the role as well as he could have given the shortcomings of the script. His signature accent and excellent line delivery gives Mills dimension. The scene where Mills is on the phone with Kims captor was hands down the best scene in the film. The scene is unique to the film; when Mills says,  I will find you, and I will kill you, it sent shivers down my spine. When he speaks he keeps you on the front edge of your chair because the tone in his voice is this weird but excellent combination of monotone and seriousness.
 I do not by any means think that Taken is a bad film but you will not be missing out on anything by giving it a pass next time you decide to sit down and watch a movie. I believe Liam Neeson fans will particularly enjoy this film, as it is another great display of his acting abilities. This film could have been great if it left you with the feeling of thinking that this could actually happen. Regardless of all of the inaccuracies, the film still made me think about the real life horrors of human trafficking.

Great summer popcorn movie... Curiously, this move was actually written for 40-something divorced males with teenage children. But it plays well with all age groups. The good guys are (mostly) good, the bad guys, however, are rotten to the core.  I was a little disappointed that the bad guy characters were so uniformly bad (and bland) and very stereotypical. The beginning of the movie was very well done... great portrait of the protagonists in life and a brief introduction to Bryan Mill's "special set of skills" left no doubt as to his core competencies. Liam Neeson did as fine a job of acting as the role allowed: subtle nuances here and there, like fatigue and irritability due to fatigue, are shown in a believable fashion (and much to the detriment to some of the antagonists). Bryan's former French Intelligence contact was well-played by Leland Orser. The movie's fast pace blurred some of the weaker scenes (particularly just before the abductions). Fun movie.

Liam Neeson has a way of speaking his lines and carrying himself that I like. I don't know where Liam is from but for some reason I like him as an actor. That said, this movie really doesn't offer much. I truly enjoyed the action part of the movie. I love how Neeson's character wasted no time in simply killing scumbags. That is the way I would do it, if I was put in such a situation or that is the way I would want to do it. Sure, in a real world you'd probably simply get killed in your first encounter with such dangerous scumbags. So it's nice to go to fantasy land where one guy can become an army of one. So, I really enjoyed the killing of scum but the rest of the movie was awful.

Neeson's daughter in this movie is that gal who I loathed from the tv show LOST. Now granted, in LOST the actresses's part was supposed to be loathsome. So to that extent the actress played her part well in LOST. But in Taken we are supposed to believe the actress is a teenager, that she is worth saving and so on. I didn't find the character to be worth saving. The girl was living a new life with her wife's new husband. Neeson's character bought the daughter a Karaoke machine while the new sugar daddy bought his new daughter a horse. And the wife was quite loathsome as well. Why would this character who is cast as a loser even care about such people. And there was no chemistry between Neeson's character, his daughter and the ex-wife. The plot is so thin and everything is completely predictable. I never was at a loss for anything. Everything was laid out like a 200 thread count sheet. The plot was weak, weak, weak. The family was weak, weak, weak. It was just so obvious that the director was throwing up a family so they could get to the action scenes which were fun. And I don't know but perhaps Neeson is also to blame for the family stuff not working. Maybe a more accomplished actor could have made the family more believable but I didn't believe this so called family, or ex family for one minute. To me the family was just stage and prop. So I'm saying the movie has no depth. The movie was lame. What more can I say.

This movie has a great premise -- a taut nightmare for any parent -- and superb actors. If you sort of blur your eyes in many of the scenes, then you'll find it plausible as well. I just wish more attention had been paid to visualizing the details of what is on the face of it a very believable, gripping scenario.

There should be more stories about human trafficking, an unconscionable crime that goes on every day. To put the issue in an action movie with such top-flight talent is a good way to do it. I found Liam Neeson grimly entrancing, the setting gorgeous, and the hand-to-hand fight scenes fast and exciting. In general, the pacing and dialogue drew me in. However, it's a shame that the story includes so many tropes of the lazy action-movie writer: dodging automatic gunfire in an enclosed space (or taking cover behind car doors and sofas), keeping up with a car on foot, hot-wiring a car without any tools for getting into the steering column or stripping the wires, and (my favorite) "processing" a digital photo to magically increase its resolution. They add a new one on me, impersonating a Frenchman in France while speaking only American English.

The creators might say that these things are necessary in order to keep up the pace and to tell the story of one man in a lonely pursuit (rather than a team story). But instead of drawing viewers in by encouraging them to pay attention, the movie just hopes you won't notice or care about the holes.

Do you remember the middle of the last decade, when we good Americans were all down on the French and when Bill O'Reilly vowed to drink no more Cotes-du-Rhone and eat no more brie?  The days of "freedom fries," in fact?  From that era (2006-07), here's a movie that shows us a real American -- willing to kill, maim, and torture in order to protect his 17-year-old baby girl.  Of course, he's played by an Irish actor, but let's forget that for the moment.  And at the beginning of the movie, we learn that his shallow wife has divorced him (he had been spending too much time protecting his country, presumably also killing, maiming, and torturing, because he's awfully good at these kinds of things), and now he has retired in order to try to maintain some contact with his daughter.  His daughter, who has clearly taken on the shallow values of her mother and stepfather, wants to go to Paris with a friend, but that turns out to be a lie.  She doesn't tell her dad that she really wants to follow U-2 around Europe because she knows that her dad won't sign the permission papers for that.  Hell, Dad doesn't feel real good about signing the permission paper for Paris.  But Mom is all for it, and Dad gives in and signs, even though he has a bad feeling about it.  Then on the very first afternoon in Paris, she's kidnapped and is about to be sold into what used to be called "white slavery" by a bunch of Albanians.

Dad is Liam Neeson, and he's a very competent killer, formerly employed by the US Government on matters of national security.  He has recently retired, so his skills have not atrophied.  He can avoid hails of AK-47 bullets, while dispatching his pursuers with well-placed single shots, and he can drive a car at speed the wrong way on Paris's one-way-streets like nobody's business.  By the time he gets on to the boat on the Seine where is daughter is being held, we know that the 10 or 12 men on the boat are as good as dead -- and very soon they are.

This is one of these movies where style or presentation trumps moral judgment.  You can't fault the pacing or the production values, and the visceral excitement of the chases and the fights tends to distract us from the fact that this a man who will torture and who is willing to kill even innocent people to do what has to be, in his view, done.  There's no remorse, no second guessing, no weighing the cost to his soul.  At the end, returning his daughter to the shallow mother, he seems untroubled by the whole experience, and his daughter seems remarkably untraumatized too: they haven't counted the cost -- because the genre of the movie won't let them -- to others or to themselves.  Liam is so untroubled that he doesn't even say to his ex-wife, "I told you so" -- so, you see, he IS capable of restraint.  He's not a monster. . .

This is a cynical and dishonest movie, pandering to the most dubious instincts of its historical moment.  Dick Cheney would have loved it, and maybe even Bill O'Reilly  . . . except that the director is FRENCH, for heaven's sake!  And the French in the movie are incompetent and corrupt, mere bureaucrats and not real soldiers for freedom.  But the French director and backers of this movie were savvy and cynical enough to know that a movie that ran down their own country might make a boatload of money in the States.  And so it did.

NOTE: My daughter had another reservation:  Neeson's character's total lack of interest in the other girls who have been put in his daughter's position.  He helps one, but only because he thinks she knows where his daughter is.  What about the rest?  After all, are these sloppy and corrupt French really going to make sure that they're OK . . .  The whole thing is quite deplorable really.

...and if you like high body counts, gruesome and violent deaths handed out to despicable characters, and generalized high-octane mayhem, this is a great film. Sometimes I'm in the mood for something violent, but I often get too involved with the lead characters, worrying about the next bad thing that's going to happen, getting all tense, and end up not enjoying the show (I had to stop Reservoir Dogs about twenty times and come back to it to finish it. Breaking Bad? Had to quit watching it entirely).

Enter likable, non-meathead Badass Bryan Mills (caveat: I gotta say that if he were played by, say, Vin Diesel or some other muscled-up dude, I would have hated him and given this zero stars). I love not having to worry about Bryan Mills, as he is indestructible and unstoppable, a professional in a world of amateurs, dealing death with abandon and in some cases glee. He is three steps ahead of everyone at all times and is an absolute expert at freaking everything from fisticuffs to high-performance driving to torture to administering intravenous drugs. He will humiliate and beat, pistol-whip, shoot, stab, maim, or otherwise incapacitate everyone foolish enough to stand in his path. Even while handcuffed to an overhead pipe and being garroted, you know those six thugs trying to finish him off have seconds to live and it's just damn beautiful.

No, it's not realistic in any way, shape, or form--I mean, really, how many crimes (murders!) did he commit in 72 hours while still getting out of France with nary a gendarme to be seen?-- but for pure testosterone-fueled bullet-ridden ass-kicking turn-off-your-brain, bad-guys-get-what's-coming-to-'em fun, Taken is nearly as good as the last three 007 films. Loved it.

This movie starts with an easy to follow beginning and quickly develops into a non-stop action thriller.  Liam Neeson was so believable in this role and he showed the world what action is all about.  An incredible performance.
Luc Besson has done it again.  As when I choose a book to read, I look at who created it.  Koontz, Brown, Tolkien, King, I know I will like, Luc Besson is the Tolkien of the screen in my view.  If Luc Besson's name appears, I know it will be a kick-butt movie.
I look for small details in action movies, the hero with a revolver that fires 100 rounds without an ammo change is fantasy, but Besson's movies have great detail and authenticity.  No one is perfect, but I see in this movie the hero puts a bullet into an enemy to make sure they don't get up again, and when he runs out of ammo, he reloads or picks up someone else's gun, (and actually checks to see if it's loaded), before taking care of more business.
Here is a director and actor who took the time and effort into making things exciting, believable and accurate.
Take it from someone who has seen a little "real" action, this movie shows it the way things should be done.  Take down the bad guy, make sure he doesn't get up and move on to the next threat.  Focus on the objective and do not let ANYTHING or ANYONE deter you from your path.  Dirtbags,(bad guys), should have no rights and receive no mercy, (loved the scene with the electricity), as they have none for their victims.
My only complaint or rather wish, would have been a little more back story or some involvement of his friends from the old days.  Maybe a Takken 3?

This is hands down one of the better movies in regards to being action-based as well as exposing the mostly hidden world of human trafficking and sex slave trading. I would recommend all to watch this at some point.

Even if objectively this is a rather silly film, I still had GREAT TIME watching this guilty pleasure. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.

Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson) is a retired super-secret super-spy. Some time earlier his wife Lenore (Famke Janssen) dumped him for a rich older guy and took his daughter Kim (Maggie Grace) with her. It was only after his retirement that Bryan could move to California to be closer to his now 17-years old daughter, but it is difficult to him to re-connect with Kim, as his former wife hates his guts and sabotages his efforts in every possible way. It doesn't help also that Kim's stepfather is obscenely rich and spoils her silly and that Kim herself is a jaded brat with brains of a gerbil...

Then Kim goes to Paris with her slightly older, slutty and even more spoiled and brainless friend Amanda - and both girls get abducted by a gang of Albanian pimps... This will give Bryan a dreamed oportunity to humble his shrewish former wife, rub the face of her new husband in dirt, compensate finally for all the past humiliations, release all the accumulated anger and frustration and especially show to his daughter how much he really loves her. In the process the population of France, Albania and Saudi Arabia  will get significantly smaller...)))

Now, objectively, this is a very, VERY silly film, with some moments really outlandishly funny, like when we learn that in Paris, France the "baguette" is actually apparel...))) On anover hand however, the bad guys are so abject and Bryan's cause so noble (save his teen age daughter from being repeteadly raped until death follows), that it is a pure DELIGHT to see Liam Neeson cut his way through Paris underworld like a terminally pissed combined harvester through wheat...)))

Being myself a father of two daughters I couldn't help but LOVE the sight of rapists, pimps, women-trafficking slavers as well as their accomplices being viciously tortured, shot, stabbed, beaten to death, eviscerated, emasculated, beheaded, crushed with heavy engineering machines, drowned, set on fire, clubbed, thrown under speeding trucks, choked, boiled with hot steam, etc, etc.

Liam Neeson delivers an IMPRESSIVE performance in this film - honestly, even Chuck Norris would probably hesitate before going toe to toe against Bryan Mills...))) Famke Janssen also is excellent as a very attractive and distinguished cynical shrewish gold digger whom we want to bitch-slap every time she appears on the screen and Maggie Grace is even better as a teen aged girl who, even if she has the maturity and the IQ of a recently planted radish, can manipulate her dear old silly daddy into virtually anything...)))

If "Taken" is not taken too seriously, this is an absolutely delightful action film. Enjoy!

Ever since I first saw this movie, I wanted to buy it. Human trafficking (especially of children/girls) is a huge issue around the world (and most people are unaware of it), and this movie is great because it raises awareness of the problem and the "bad guys" get what's coming to them. Finally, justice! It's a touching story with the dad going after his daughter, too. The extended edition definitely had some footage & extra scenes I didn't remember seeing the first time I saw this film, so I was glad I bought it. It's also not overly violent because it doesn't show over-the-top gory details of the people who are killed. The subject matter is definitely adult though re: drugs, forced prostitution, murder, etc. & it's suspenseful and keeps you on the edge of your seat. My husband thinks some of the tactics are far-fetched but I like it (reminds me of Mission Impossible) because I want to believe that a highly trained operative could solve this kind of crime. I've also seen Taken 2, which is decent, but definitely not as good as this first one.
Some great action and pure revenge...no frills....no political correctness....just rage.  I love it...even if it is a story of a guy kicking ass in his late 50s

Man who is former US government CIA assassin type is now retired and trying to build a relationship with his teenage daughter after having missed out on her life because his former job took him around the world for weeks and months at a time. His marriage has been over for a  while because of his job. His ex-wife is now married to a wealthy man in LA. Daughter cons father, with mother's help, to go to Paris alone with her rich female friend. They get kidnapped. Father has 96 hours to find them.

This movie is about white slavery. The sex trade. You lots of young girls being drugged and used as prostitutes by men in France. There is lots of violence. Graphic violence. There is a race to recover the girl before she is shipped off to a Muslim who "purchased" her. The spoiled brat girl and the stupid mother make it really hard to like them. And you forget this is a movie. It just leaves you with a sick feeling in your stomach knowing that this goes on around the world all them time. And most of these young girls don't have rich step fathers or ex-CIA assassin fathers with contacts to save them. Hell, some of the girls sold into the sex trade have parents who sold them. . . think India. It just reminds you of the sick world we live in and most of us aren't touched by.

TAKEN Produced by Luc Besson and Directed by some other French Director
i don't watch french films apart from Luc Besson's Directed films
everything about this film is excellent
Liam neeson steals the whole film of course, excellent written story, brilliantly Directed
i'm sure some of the scenes were Directed by Luc besson himself, but the credit goes to Pierre
the plot is basically about Liam's character Bryan's Daughter Maggie Grace who's been taken by Albanians in Paris
for Human trafficking and Bryan goes to get her back
some of the scenes are very Disturburbing especially the sex Hostel where many Girls have been
Drugged with Heroin and sold for sex
but Brilliant Directing, excellent performances by Maggie Grace and Liam neeson
it's full throttle edge of your seat from the first scene to the last scene
there's 2 versions the Theatrical version 90mins including credits
and the Unrated version which includes about 2mins of extra footage mainly more violence
i prefer the Unrated version myself
the blu-ray version has more special features, making of featurettes than the DVD
so best to get the blu-ray version
i definitely gave it 5 stars no Doubt about it

i've also seen the sequel TAKEN 2, which is basically the same film redone again
so i wasn't fully blown away with this sequel as i was with the original
probably about 50% blown away with this sequel
the sequel starts where the first one finished
where the father of one of the Drug dealers/traffickers that Bryan tortured/killed in the first film
 sets out for revenge on Bryan and his family with flashback scenes from the first film
and this time Bryan and his wife get Taken by the Albanians in Istanbul
while Maggie Grace tries to rescue her mom and dad
i couldn't see the point really on this sequel but just as much action as the first film
But still Liam neeson steals the film, aswell as Famke jansen and Maggie grace
Great performances No Doubt
so if you watch TAKEN, then you better to watch TAKEN 2 right after you finish the first film
cause the plot continues on from the first film

there's not much extras at all on the DVD or blu-ray version of TAKEN 2
there's no making of Documentary or anything
just a 3mins featurette on Sams tools of the Trade which just talks about his weapons really
and a 5-10mins interview with Liam neeson on TAKEN 2 that's all
the first film deserves 5 stars, the sequel deserves about 3-3.5 stars
but if you buy TAKEN 1, also get TAKEN 2 at the same time

First off, the mediocre rating I'm giving the movie is not because of the film's cinematic quality, it's because of the video problems I'm experiencing.  I'm not going to review the movie; it's old enough that it really doesn't need one more person's assessment (I really did like it though).  Although I am not having an issue playing the disc at all, as many 1-star reviewers have noted, I experienced horrible macro-blocking and strange light/dark bands flashing on the screen for about 2/3 of the movie.  I had rented the DVD years ago, and I actually like the movie (shameless action movie entertainment) but I wanted the Blu Ray version.  I don't know if anybody else has had the same issue as me, but you can clearly see very distracting pixelated areas in dark scenes, and huge bands about 1/3 of the height of my 1080p tv where the colors alternate between darker and lighter shades of the rest of the screen, and it kept alternating, so I would see a light picture across the top and bottom, dark across the center, and it would flip around and alternate, just to make sure I didn't forget about it and actually enjoy the movie. I played it on my PC's blu-ray player with PowerDVD 13.  I will try it in my Panasonic player, and maybe the PS3 to be sure, but I haven't had issues with any other discs.  I watched Pacific Rim, Oblivion, Man of Steel, and I Am Legend, all new (to me) Blu-Rays this week without a hitch.  Also, the back of my movie's case had a 2" cut down the center, as if a carpet knife or box-cutter had gotten to it.  The discs reveal no physical damage damage at all.

Liam Neeson plays an agent who retires so he can reconnect with his 16 year-old daughter, who has grown up with his ex-wife and her second husband. When the daughter gets a chance to accompany her best friend on a trip to Paris, her father reluctantly gives her permission, but makes her promise to call him as soon as she gets there. During that phone call both girls are violently abducted while the father, helpless, listens. The rest of the movie is his desperate, frantic attempt to find and rescue her before she is sold as a sex slave. Graphic violence, car chases, fights.  I enjoyed it and my husband loved it.

Second, this movie is honest enough not to portray the White slavers as either a. Germans b. upper-class English, or  c. American Southerners, which are the three choices you have when casting bad guys in movies. This film courageously identifies the villains as Albanians, who are, in reality- the reigning pimps, fencers, drug smugglers and all-around scum of Europe. Such a plot element is_very_politically incorrect (since the Albanians are predominantly Moslem) but_very_honest.

I don't normally enjoy action films like this because I always feel like the story lines tend to be woven around glorified action sequences. This film, however, is amazing. It's not just given the "action" title for the sake of blowing stuff up; It's an actual thriller.
Liam Neeson went above and beyond in this role. It makes you never want anyone to mess with him. And while I'm not a parent myself, I can see how the premise of this film could potentially terrify a parent; No one wants their child taken hostage. God forbid my future children get taken hostage, but if that ever happens, I'd legitimately want someone like Liam Neeson to be there to get them back.
All of that being said, I highly recommend this film. I enjoyed it so much that I inevitably made everyone around me watch it for themselves. (They all enjoyed it. And I'm sure you will, too.)

Taken is the sort of film where you pretty much need to leave your common sense at the door and just have a good time. Yes it's about as predictable as it get's, and there are some issues that make it rather silly. Liam Neeson is a superb actor but as dumb as it sounds this role would be better suited for someone like Kiefer Sutherland. Basically the character Neeson plays is Jack Bauer with a different face. But a more important issue is how silly the whole story is. Neeson's character is a highly trained ex-government agent who has a daughter who wants to travel to Europe following U2's tour dates as they travel. Neesun's character knows the world all too well and is concerned for her safety. He tries to talk her out of it knowing how dangerous it is to travel to another country. To make a long story short- He gives in an let's her go. Well she arrives, and in less than a few hours She get's kidnapped by criminals who want to sell her on the black market as a sex slave. Like the audience is actually supposed to swallow such nonsense? Naturally he must go and rescue his daughter on his own, and he expertly kills at least 50 people on his journey until he finally finds her. He's (of course) left almost unwounded through the entire affair. The good news is that the film is filled with some excellent and well crafted action sequences that make it worth seeing. But if you are a 24 fan it's nothing you haven't seen a hundred times. Basically the film is a brainless action movie, but it is a great deal of fun to watch anyway.

The setting is, mostly, Paris and the star is Irish, but this is a
distinctly American story: given that the authorities are bound to be
incompetent or corrupt, you have to go rogue to get anything done,
such as saving your daughter from white slavers. This is a brutal
film, with an unending supply of bad guys and only one good guy, and
the suspense is tremendous. What holds it together, really, is Neeson's
steely command--amid all the action, he is steadfast, smart, and
incredibly resourceful. Don't as much as blink, because the surprises
come so suddenly that you'll miss them.

I have wanted to watch this movie ever since it came out.  Okay, I'm too cheap to get a Netflix membership, too lazy to go to a DVD store and am VERY patient.  So when I saw this movie could be rented and downloaded right to my computer for less than three bucks, I popped up the popcorn and enjoyed a great flick with the expected wonderful acting by Liam Neeson and crew and the typical suspense/good guy rocks factor. Pretty predictable as a movie goes, but still well worth my pittance paid out for it.

This is NOT normally the type of movie that I gravitate towards (lots of violence), but it was easy to be taken in with the good guy/bad guy plot and rooting for the good guy. The basic storyline is that a retired anti-terrorist type of guy's daughter gets kidnapped and he goes to rescue her. In the context of that story, I was able to cheer when all the murder and mayhem happened.

The action NEVER lags. Even though the movie is largely about "beat up this guy, kill that guy" the way in which it is done is entertaining. Since dad has 96 hours to find his daughter, you always have the sense that time is running out. This makes the movie move very fast.

Liam Neeson is always good. The other actors are also good. The weak link would be the daughter though. She acts goofy (running everywhere with her hair flying), but it doesn't detract too much.

If you like action and violence, you'll like it.
We actually watched Taken 2 first it was so good I had to buy this one and totally enjoyed it as well.

Taken is an enjoyable film for what it is.  The plot is nothing new.  Many other action films have similar plots like Commando.  So, it all comes down to how well and different it is executed.  I think Taken is executed fairly decently.  Though, this is mainly due to Liam Neeson and his performance, like in the famous telephone scene.  Without Neeson, this movie would not be nearly as enjoyable.

The acting is alright.  No one did a bad job performance wise.  The only character worth talking about is Bryan Mills, played by Liam Neeson.  He is very likable, very driven, and kicks ass.  There are times were he comes off very mean and extreme.  However, I still liked him as a character, because of his situation.  I'm glad he came out on top in the end.  The rest of the characters are bland.  Maggie Grace's character is the typical teenage girl that gets kidnapped.  I did kind of feel for her, but not much, because I barely got to know her.  Famke Janssen, I did not care for at all.  She did nothing, and was very mean throughout most of the film.  The villains, I thought, were kind of nothing villains.  I did not find them intimidating.

The film does move at a good pace.  The action scenes are fun and well-choreographed.  The final fight I really enjoyed.

Overall this is a generic, but fun action movie.  Its saving grace is definitely Liam Neeson and his character.  I recommend this to people who are fans of action movies.  Those who are not fans of action films, I would skip this.

This is not the version I bought. I bought the extended single disc. I read about the movie recently and was interested in the subject matter. White slavery, as it is called, kidnapping young women and selling them for sex, is a rapid growth industry these days. Most Americans are not aware it exists. I bought the movie as a curiosity. This thing is not a documentary. It is an action popcorn feature flick with lots of gunfights, car chases and big explosions, but the core of the plot is dead on. Teenage girls go to Europe and are kidnapped by thugs and sold for prostitution. I have watched this DVD several times since it arrived and have not tired of it yet.

By David Feeney, Author Terror On The High Seas As I've said before, every decade has a film or two in the action genre that defines the age; Dirty Harry 70s, Lethal Weapon & First Blood 80s, Point Break 90s. I remember spotting a commercial for Taken on YouTube several months before the film arrived in the US. The film opened in Europe and made it's way slowly about the world. I kept tracking its earnings and was psyched to see it. I was not disappointed. Taken is a relentless action film. When Brian Mills' (Neeson)daughter is taken by sex slave traders while on a trip to Paris, Mills, a former CIA special services type springs into action. Seldom does a move live up to it's trailer. Usually the trailer showcases the best action scenes to lure an audience in. Not so with Taken. Taken delivers on the promise of its trailer. Daughter taken + Daddy goes ballistic = lots of dead scumbags! I cannot overemphasize this last point. Every scene in this film serves only to give Neeson more people to kill...all to our delight. I saw this in a theater with a good crowd. People were cheering with every shattered skull, ruptured larynx, bullet between the eyes or steak knife to the heart. Neeson is a force of nature as he moves from one act of carnage to the next. He even shoots his friend's wife! How's that for badass? There's also some great dialogue to boot. 'I'll tear down the Eiffel tower if I have to!' (He says this to his friend in the French Secret Service!) 'Now's not the time for dick measuring, Stuart!' (He says this to his X-wife's new husband!) 'You either give me what I need or this switch will stay on until they turn the power off for lack of payment on the bill.' (He says this to a dude he's electrocuting) and who could forget... 'I don't know who you are. I don't know what you want. If you are looking for ransom, I can tell you I don't have money. But what I do have are a very particular set of skills; skills I have acquired over a very long career. Skills that make me a nightmare for people like you. If you let my daughter go now, that'll be the end of it. I will not look for you, I will not pursue you. But if you don't, I will look for you, I will find you, and I will kill you.' Jeepers. I'm ttrembling as I type this. Be warned, there's no philosophy here. No attempt to understand why they do what they do. Nobody plants a placenta in a garden or remembrance or any of that nonsense. Neeson just leaves the dirty buggers behind. I don't know how many people he kills in this movie. I tried to count but lost track in all the excitement. For those of you who haven't seen Taken see it. And just remember...there is a Taken 2. And yes, the dummies come after him again. But no, it's not as good as the first. Enjoy.
Ex-CIA agent Liam Neesom has to recover a kidnapped young woman who will end up in the White Slavery trade in 96 hours.  Well done but it is an adult show with torture, shootings and death.

The toughest part of making a good action film is the story. When creating an action film, it's very easy for the director to get "action happy" and leave the story behind. What makes "Taken" special is how while the story is nothing complex or mind boggling, the prelude into the action is done in such a way where you truly care about Bryan Mills, (Neeson) so later on when the action picks up it's not mindless, we are in Neeson's corner.

"Taken" is about a divorced man named Bryan Mills. He is an ex C.I.A. operative which drew him away from his family. Now retired, he decides to move closer to his only daughter who he at best has a rocky relationship with. His daughter Kim is invited to spend the weekend in Paris with some friends, but needs her father's signature in order to leave the country. Reluctantly, he signs the papers with numerous conditions that she must follow. When Kim and her friend arrive in Paris, Kim's friend reveals to her and a random, handsome looking man they shared a cab with that they have the apartment all to themselves. This mysterious man from the cab volunteers to pick the two girls up for a party he invited them to. However, when he returns, he brings his fellow East Europe gang members who kidnap the two girls and begin to sell them into prostitution. Bryan Mills uses his skills from the C.I.A. to rescue his daughter.

While this plot seems simple and overdone in the film industry, what makes this film work is how director Pierre Morel works the character development and the wonderful performance from Liam Neeson.

If you're in the mood for a good edge-of-your-seat action flick, then Taken is for you. So long as you realize up front that it's relatively mindless, you won't be let down.

Never go to Europe. Never! It's pretty much a foregone conclusion that you'll be groomed and sold into sex slavery the literal second you step off the plane. Paris in particular is swarming with prozzies and greasy crooks from some former Soviet block hellhole who kidnap pretty young girls, hook them on drugs, and sell them to morbidly obese Sultans while setting-up sex cabins on building sites, holding sex eBays in the basements of upper class parties, and living in all-male rape communes with the proceeds from their unscrupulous businesses being kept in a coffee can on the kitchen shelf.

And producer/director Luc Besson and Pierre Morel are French too, so they know what they are talking about. Liam Neeson knows it too, but his sullen ex-wife believes the world to be full of sunshine and candy and has no problem with sending their unnaturally juvenile 17-year-old daughter off to Paris with her slut best friend. Just as daddy predicted, the dirty foreign animals grab her and hoist her away for auction.

Luckily for daddy he has a very particular set of skills that make him a nightmare for foreigners and he goes off to Paris to raise hell. The detective element is played down, down, down (Neeson collects hair samples for no particular reason, never bothers to hide his accent) and the merciless xenophobia is cranked up, up, up. It's not much different from Death Wish in that the crimes established in the first act are merely there to justify the sadism that follows.

The film is not that vivid however. Had it been made in the 80s I am sure that the violence would be visceral and effective, but in the post-Bourne world it's shot and cut in a way where you can't really see anything, regardless of which version you are watching.

The material is thin, the action is only slightly above tepid, and the killing never really goes beyond gunplay. Taken was a huge, surprise hit when released in the US in early 2009 (several months after its European release) and seemed to naturally tap into America's distrust of other nations and hunger for killing.

If you want to take the movie's advice then it's best to stay on US soil, where no one has ever been the victim of violence.

My adult kids know how much I love watching my boys Segal, Van Damme & Norris. My youngest (27) suggested I watch Taken as Leeson is the new Segal. Wrong! At least my fellas make now bones about the action thriller movies they make. Taken was cheezy and unimpressive.

Bryan (played by Liam Neeson), retired, has very special skills honed while a top-notch field agent for the American CIA. Bryan is also a divorced, very divorced from his ex-wife's perspective, parent of a precocious teenage daughter with singing aspirations and a yen to head to Europe, Paris first stop, in order to follow the international rock group U-2 (?-for a 2008 teenager but we will let that pass). Those Bryan honed spy skills turned out to come in very handy, once he relented and let that wayward daughter head to Europe. See almost as soon as she (and her dippy friend, her older girlfriend) , as single good-looking teenagers on the loose, are spotted and violently kidnapped by a nefarious international gang of white-slavers who are looking to place young girls in their whorehouses or sell them off to the highest bidder.

Thus, we have the perfect storm between a man with a ruthless set of spy skills and a previously neglected daughter in distress and Bryan must use every one of them before he is through. The bulk of the film revolves around Bryan chasing, hitting, shooting, beating, torturing, shooting (oh, I said that), interrogating, driving, leaping, mano y mano fighting, and just plain being a mal hombre as he works his way through the litany of bad guy involved in the white-slave trade from lowly thuggish Albanians (who seemingly collectively cannot fight off one guy) to middle- man pimp daddy French society figures to paid off French security agents to oil-soaked depraved sheiks who specialize in deflowering young girls before he saves his still chaste daughter (naturally) and sends her back to California and a grateful mother, and more respectful ex-wife.

Recently in reviewing another protective parent drama, 2001s The Deep End,  I noted that I had been listening to a "high brow" talking- head discussion about the sea-change that has been occurring in the way American parenting has evolved over the past thirty years or so (the speakers however covered themselves with the caveat that this trend excluded certain ethnic, racial, cultural and class exceptions, in short, this was about how middle, now middle, and upper class parents raise their progeny the cohort of that and this film). The gist of the argument was that the new "coddle" generation (say those under thirty, okay) have never learned to fail, their parents have never allowed them to experience failure, and therefore they have never learned how to fly out of the nest unaided and therefore are ill-equipped to face the wicked old world and its snares. And that is a future problem, no question. However I would amend that statement here and say that old Bryan, with remarkably few scars, won the parent of the year award here, protective or not.

I purchased this CD for my daughter and grandchildren to watch and insisted that they watch the CD prior to my daughter and granddaughter's trip to New York last year.  My daughter and granddaughter were also quite insistent that it was safe for my granddaughter to travel alone to Korea to visit one of her Korean friends.  Instead of watching only a little bit of the CD, my daughter and grandchildren were spell bound and could not stop watching this CD and learning from it.  The contents were instilled in their minds, so much so, any future plans for my granddaughter to travel alone to Korea have been squelched.  Also my granddaughter who prior to the film told her Mom that she wanted to be with her friends while in New York and didn't want her Mom to be following her around now begged her Mom not to let her out of her sight.  You can tell young and older people about what to be careful of when traveling, etc.; however seeing what could happen and did happen is ever so much more powerful than the spoken words.  This DVD should be shown to all young teens and older students plus their parents.

A parent's protective, desperate fury is a fantastic vehicle for justifying the kind of unabashed mayhem and destruction that Taken delivers.  Liam Neeson channels righteous anger in very focused ways, making some of the questionable things his character does seem purposeful, despite running counter to what the ideal action hero would do.

The primary story of an abducted daughter, kidnapped on a trip her estranged father felt was too dangerous in the first place, almost would have performed better against a generic backdrop of "some other city".  The unique character of Paris and the foreign way that police and intelligence matters are handled served as unnecessary distractions.

At the end of the day, the design of the movie feels like a good idea hijacked by movie execs.  Light spoiler alert, but as an example, the movie's hero moves mainly unscathed through numerous violent encounters with villains until, surprise, the super-evil and smarmy looking second-in-command manages to wound him in a gunfight.  Fear not, as he was ruthlessly, but justifiably, stabbed by his own knife/impaled on a stick/thrown down a well.  Honestly, I can't remember as I had really started to lose interest in the specifics by this point, but I hope you get the general idea.

Taken is probably best watched when you're at home, sick with the flu, passing in and out of consciousness from the lingering effects of last night's Ny-Quil.  It's not horrible by any stretch, but ends up as a bit of a disappointment.

This isn't an intelligent film, but it is a simple action film told in a very fun way. You cannot get more simple than an estranged  father, trying NOT to be estranged, while everyone else; ex wife, daughter and ex wife's new husband, doing everything in their power to keep him estranged, and then showing this man on the outside being the ONLY one who can save the daughter after she is kidnapped and is about to be sold into the sex trade. He does everything he can do to find his unappreciative spoiled, but missing daughter. More importantly, he has a special set of skills that are useful in tracking and killing anyone who gets in the way of him finding his daughter. Now, add Liam Neeson and martial arts, and you have a high octane mix ready to blow you away.  There is no deep thoughts here...no mystery, no thriller twists, just a hard hammered fist of a man plowing through people, trying to find his little girl.  As the father of a little girl, I loved it. I would have loved it anyway, because, I love anything with Liam Neeson.

I never thought of Liam Neeson as an action movie lead, but he manages to do very well in this movie.  Good story and good action from start to finish!

Can one man take on scores of bad guys, and come away with little more than a few scratches and bruises?  No.  But any dad who watches this movie will see himself doing the same thing for his daughter.  The characters are believable, but the action sequences are not so much.  The thing that detracts from the realism, that many movies are guilty of, is how the lower-level bad guys get taken out of commission with one punch or kick, while the bosses take several minutes to incapacitate.  I didn't see it in the theater, and I don't regret that decision.  It's a great action flick, but not on the level of a Bourne movie, or a Bond movie.

First, I don't like that Amazon integrates all the various formats into one review section.

Second, as a movie review, I really like this movie. I know a lot is unbelievable and even impossible. I like the basic storyline and the intense action. It also hits on a real life issue of human trafficking. Exposing issues like this may help make people be more aware and help to stop such heinous acts. Again, as a movie, I think some people are reading too much into it giving it undo lowered ratings. Movies are for entertainment and this movie is entertaining. I  think Shrek is an entertaining movie and I don't expect to see a large green ogre appearing around the corner.

Third, as a bluray DVD which I purchased, I am very disappointed. The quality of the picture is only about equivalent to a standard DVD and the dark scenes are very grainy looking worse than VHS if any of you out there even remember VHS. Some good with the DVD format is the extra scenes and a cool death/injured counter throughout the movie. Again, all for your entertainment.

Overall, I give the movie a strong 4.5 stars and the bluray disc only 3 stars giving a total of 3.75 stars for the bluray movie of Taken.

Do you love unadulterated, undiluted, unfiltered, pure, genuine, raw AWESOME!? Then Taken will have to file a restraining order against you, because you're about to send it a "fan letter" gushing about how much you love it, in individually cut-out newspaper and magazine letters. After putting this piece of cinematic history-making bliss into your DVD player, one of two things will happen: You'll never be able to hit the eject button, or, you'll fall victim to spontaneous combustion after witnessing such skull fracturing terrorist slaying wickedly gnarly coolness, exuded by the then little known William John Neeson. Read on...

Liam (Or "Li-li" as I call him) is a cherished friend of mine, and when we hang out on the weekends when our schedules allow, it's such a blast drudging up ole' set stories from all the insanity that ensued while filming the eventual sure-fire global sensation that was at the time titled "I was Zeus, trained Batman, and mentored Jedis, and you took my daughter!?" (It was later decided that "Taken" seemed more fitting for box office marques). Oh boy, I remember the time Liam leaned over to me off-camera between takes, and said "Hey, Aaron... give me some sort of hardcore ominous monologue that I can use when I'm on the horn with Marco from the sex-slave trading bizz," and I immediately lit up like a Christmas tree when it hit me: LIAM, TELL THEM YOU HAVE A PARTICULAR SET OF SKILLS! Now you know, the rest of the story.

If you don't own this Blu Ray DVD, Liam will find you... and he will ask to be invited in for a screening with you. He is, after all, an overly polite gentleman. So, buy this Blu Ray, because Li-Li has a habit of showing up at the earlier hours of the morning.

A young girl, Kim Mills (Maggie Grace), sets off for Europe to follow a pop group on tour. She is accompanied by her friend Amanda (Katie Cassidy). At the airport in Paris she is enticed by a young man to share a taxi to her apartment. Later, that same man has thugs kidnap Kim and Amanda to exploit them for prostitution. Now Kim's father, Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson) is an ex-CIA man and is immediately on the case. The rest of the film is about Bryan's attempts to track down the kidnappers. There's lots of action as Mills demolishes all the Albanian and Islamic opposition as he rescues his girl, but the number of victims he manages to execute while hardly sustaining a scratch himself is scarcely believable. There is a sub-plot about Kim wanting to become a pop singer herself, but there are not really many surprises in the main or sub-plot.

I found "Taken" to be standard fare for action/thrillers; it's the skillful acting and the exacting of revenge for an unspeakable crime that kept me watching and wanting more. If my daughter (or niece) was kidnapped and sold into sex slavery, I'd definitely want to do to the "bad guys" what they get in "Taken." Liam Neeson is a great actor and can convincingly play any role, and that applies to his character in this movie. Maggie Grace performs well in her role, and Famke Janssen (for whom we see too little) is also very convincing. The other bit players were well cast.

The biggest complaint I have is kind of trivial. After some of the more intense action scenes, I came to realize there wasn't any blood being spilled. Sure enough, when I slowed the movie down to single frames, none of the actors have blood packs on them when they get shot. The blood is added afterward. This was especially apparent when Neeson's character shoots someone in the face at point-blank range and instead of his head exploding, his head snaps back  no blood at all. It's a cheap way to film action sequences, but the action is fast and furious and not many people will notice that point.

I hate to say it, but this is a perfectly awful film.

Right from the start, there is something wrong with the tone of the film, as the retired agent is trying to get close to the daughter he alienated by his long and mysterious absences.  The viewer gets dished up a dripping melodrama about a painful divorce, with all the hot button scenes - trying to get her attention with a gift, his ex-wife standing in the way the whole while with bitter sarcasm, and the innocent (beautiful) daughter pampered by her new dad - that are supposed to pull at the heartstrings.  The acting was so wooden and the dialogue so stilted that I couldn't believe any of it.

Then suddenly, the tone shifts:  dad excessively worries about the daughter going to Europe on her own at 17, and sure enough, she is immediately abducted by the worst kind of guy and gang.  But dad happens to be available and puts his "special skills" to work, becoming a sudden superhero, in a blur of brutal violence, questionable methods to put it mildly, and an entry into the underworld of modern slavery and prostitution.  This section is better, if you are looking for an action film with a lone good guy fighting packs of baddies.  I enjoyed this part more, though wondered about the PG-13 rating.  It is raw, ugly, and full of blatant stereotypes.  That he rescues her - miraculously not violated or even deflowered, but right at the moment a fat ugly sheik is about to have his way with her - is to be expected.  But all credibility is lost - seeing that he is also now a criminal fugitive in France, you wonder how he gets her out.  It is so ridiculously unbelievable that I could never completely go with the flow for fun.

It is shocking how stupid this all is.  What a disappointment.  Not recommended.

A little short on the "believability" side , but GREAT on "possibility" side . i mean COULD one REALLY pull off all those stunts and action a Liam Neeson does  ; its POSSIBLE , thoe not truly believable . HOWEVER , the THINKING side ; father lost daughter to criminals ; OH YEAH !! all that destruction and MAYHEM is possible . i would give this movie 10 stars for keeping the action in  REAL WORLD . the ACTION is excellent and done with MUCH forethought and planning . Liam's character chases down a CARTEL of sex slavers wrecking half of FRANCE to find his daughter ; simple , basic theme covering all human time and emotion .
  if you want explosions and "RAMBO" , it aint here , AND still gives you a similar feel . "Never mess with mama bear" a common phrase .... well , watch this movie and see what POPPA BEAR might well do . OH YEAH !! not enough humor , is my only true complaint . too intense too long and still movie compels one to watch it over again .
  STUDY for the underlying REDEMPTION idea woven in story base . Many a blue collar guy will feel a good ARGH ARGH !! POWER !! near the end .
  POP the KORN and enjoy a wild ride where the GOOD GUY WINS .

ok i think i figured it out. its all happening in the main Characters head hes having some kind of violent fantasy . and he's absolutely nuts . half way through i was hoping the main character was wasted or locked up .  for example apparently all the Albanians ( who are the bad guys here) are ex star wars storm troopers/  i mean they fire automatic weapons  and hand guns point blank at lliam and nothing hits him.  is it all a dream or something? or maybe you have to really.. really  suspend belief .also he brutally murders two civilians  in front of police and onlookers in paris and casually walks away . no one says or does anything, no questions.  i mean come on. so he's going into peoples houses murdering them including a police chiefs wife gets in 20 minute gun fights in the middle of paris no cops ever show up. he literally murders dozens of people  over a kidnapping. than you know after murdering dozens of people including a judge and other high ranking french citizens  causally goes to the airport  no questions asked and goes home  i guess asking for realism here is to much.. its got to be a violent fantasy dream of a mad man .i didn't think this movie was well written acted or interesting it lacked complexity and depth as well. the dvd case has more depth  than this piece of garbage

Stupid!

No surprises here. Suspend belief as Liam Neeson courageously, methodically, and efficiently tracks down nasty Eurotrash and eliminates them with nary a scratch until the end. See him arrive home victorious, with no mention of any repercussions from shooting the wife of a French Big Shot to get his point across. I guess the French were all, "Oh, you crazy American!" and knew it had to be done. Predictable, yet fun to watch- who doesn't like to see an Albanian electrocuted with a home made electric chair? Perfect set up for a sequel- they get the ex-wife next. In the third one, they take his faithful dog,  Shutzengel. To make it interesting, the dog will be carrying Atomic Secrets in his collar.

Unfortunately, your thinking is all about how farcically preposterous the whole thing is.

To be honest, there is nothing that Liam Neeson's character does during any 4-second interval of the film that is not believable.  Taking all his actions together, though; that's where the absurdity comes in.

One might argue that this is meant to be a fast-paced thriller that will provide a couple of hours and entertainment and nothing more.  But for my part I couldn't lose myself in this movie on account of being unable to believe that Liam Neeson could be this sort of man, or that anybody in the world had such a skill set.

I wonder what the French thought of this film:  it was almost an insult to their culture.
