It is a feat of strength to dislike this movie.
Highly recommend it for owning and renting.
Liam neeson is badass in this movie.  He does what all fathers should do if their daughter is in danger - kick some serious ass.
This was actually a pretty good movie.  I am not actually a big fan of Neeson, but he does a good job in this movie.  Good action, good story and just good fun.

I find the story very interesting. The actors are very good, particularly
Liam Neeson is perfect. In my opinion it is one of the best thrillers.

If you like non-stop action with not too complicated a story, then this movie is for you. You may be thinking "Well, Liam Neeson is NOT an action star," and you'd be right in general, but here, he unleashes everything he's saved up in his entire career.

I didn't know what to expect when I rented this, but I'd gladly watch again. And, rest assured, at 90 minutes this movie isn't so short because it cuts out important plot points or skimps in any way; when the film is over, I didn't want any more from it. Take it for what it is-a 90-minute thrill ride, and prepare yourself for some previously unseen Neeson action! Do it. Now. One-Click that s*$#. Enjoy.

Full Disclosure: I don't know all that much about the difference between high-end and middle-of-the-road Blu-ray players, so maybe my ignorance is to blame.  In that case, take the review with a grain of salt.

Also, ***spoilers below***.

The Film: I don't know what people expect from movies - I don't know exactly how some people can think this is a 5 star movie while others think it's the worst thing ever made.  That just seems implausible.  But there's no accounting for taste, I suppose.  For me, this is what good action movies are like.  There are very few frills, the pace is a dead sprint after the initial set up, and there isn't anything in the story to get in the way of the action.  This is an action movie, right?  Maybe you want something different...in that case this movie isn't for you.  I don't think you're wrong.  I don't think you have bad taste.  I just like simple, straight forward action movies.  That's what Taken is, as far as I can tell.
Is Liam a good guy?  I don't know.  Not all movies are about good guys vs. bad guys.  Some movies are about a slightly-past-his-prime bad ass who wants his daughter back.  Oh, that's this movie.  Do you have to suspend disbelief throughout...yes...but...that's what movies are about, right?  By the end of the movie Liam's character is limping, stabbed, bruised, and exhausted.  Is it TOTALLY believable?  No, of course not.  If it were totally believable the movie would have ended with Liam heading home never to see his daughter again, probably only after the US negotiated for his release from French prison for running amok, etc.  Do you want to see that movie?  I don't.

So, the movie is simple and linear.  Ex-preventer bad ass Neeson goes and gets his daughter back leaving a trail of bodies in his wake.  Either that's your cup of tea or it isn't.

So, why the 4 star rating?  Well, the Blu-ray didn't want to cooperate with my player.  The super-impressive and action-packed menus apparently overwhelm my bottom of the heap Blu-ray player.  Call me crazy, but it seems like a blu-ray release should play on the lowest common denominator.  The movie looks and sounds great once my player grunts and slogs through the menus and gets started, but it took like 20 minutes - no kidding.  Someone please tell me that it's my player for sure and I will sort that out.  Until that time, though, I'm calling the blu-ray release a stinker.

It's been a long time since I watched an action movie and was so involved, riveted to the screen, and rooted so much for the main character as when I saw last weekend the thriller Taken (2008) written by Luc Besson and directed by Pierre Morel. As the action movies go, this is very entertaining and dynamic picture.

The plot involves the kidnapping of an American girl (Maggie Grace) vacationing with a friend in Paris, by the gang of Albanian human traffickers specializing in selling young women into forced prostitution. Her estranged father Bryan (Liam Neeson), a retired CIA agent, the member of the elite "Special Activities Division" Black operations is on the phone with his daughter at the very moment of kidnapping and he's got just a few days to find out who is behind the crime and to try to get his daughter back before it is too late. If you've seen the trailer for the movie, the Neeson's close up and his short but convincing speech addressed to the invisible unknown man who is listening to his daughter's cell phone, tell you everything you have to know: "I don't know who you are. I don't know what you want. If career. Skills that make me a nightmare for people like you. If you let my daughter go now, that'll be the end of it. I will not look for you, I will not pursue you. But if you don't, I will look for you, I will find you, and I will kill you." The film follows this statement closely, and makes it a really fast running 93 you are looking for ransom, I can tell you I don't have money. But what I do have are a very particular set of skills; skills I have acquired over a very long minutes. The plot is anything but new - back in 1985 Arnold Schwarzenegger as retired elite commando had only a few hours to find and rescue his daughter from an exiled dictator. The first and by far the best season of hit TV series 24 had Kiefer Sutherland as LA based CTU Agent Jack Bauer chasing of all sorts of terrorists who taken his teenage daughter. In its bets moments, Taken brings as much excitement and adrenalin as these classics. Another thought came to my mind while watching the movie, if ever Liam Neeson was considered for the part of Bond, James Bond? If not 007 himself, he could have easily been s Bond's older brother, less glamorous but as dangerous and deadly.

Taken touches on horrific but sadly existing and blooming business of international women trafficking, the slave trade of our times. Do not expect the movie make some serious social comments or provide the deep insight into the dirtiest business possible. Neeson's hero is not out to save thousands of lost forever young women, he is trying to find and safe one girl only who just happened not to know how lucky she was to have a deadly killing machine for a dad. I don't recall when was last time I felt as satisfied as when Bryan let disgusting and despicable villains of different social standings have it with great vengeance and furious anger. I saw perfectly clear all movie's weaknesses and clichs while I was watching it but it never bored me, it was non-stopping action, and it had a hero whom I desperately want to succeed. Perfect or not - I liked Taken a lot and would recommend it without hesitation.

This was a pretty good one, though like another poster said, Liam Neeson hasn't done any bad films, IMO. It is satisfying and exciting, especially since all the bad guys are preying on innocent girls. They deserve whatever they get, all of them, only more slowly. As with any kind of "right vs wrong" story, I wonder how those who started out as human beings, with hearts and souls, became so devoid of humanity that they would do these horrible things without blinking an eye.

The one thing that really really REALLY annoyed me was the exwife. She clearly had her issues with Neeson's character as a husband, and that was fine, but to see her take every opportunity to interfere and take verbal jabs and sabotage his relationship with his daughter was infuriating, as well as really bad parenting. No one in their right mind would just say, "oh you want to go bebop around Europe alone, with no supervision of any kind? Sure let me sign the permission," without even having a moment to think about it. Of course IMO no parent in their right mind would let their teen daughter do it anyway. It seemed as though the exwife was willing to send their daughter into as risky a situation as she could, just to spite Neeson, with his concerns born of knowledge. I wanted her at the end to just say she was wrong, but all she would say was "bring her back to ME," as though Neeson were merely the deliveryman, and had no real emotional stake in it. I thought it was pretty cold of the daughter to leave him alone at the airport as well. It seemed that both parents consisted basically of trying to outdo each other in giving the daughter everything she wanted, not stellar parenting there either.

While there was quite a bit of implausibility, the thing that got me was that the rich dudes at the auction would pay hundreds of thousands of dollars for sex with a virgin girl? I mean, really? I am no expert on this but it seems to me that that is alot of money for something not that big a deal. It seems more likely to me that people would pay more for "different," less mainstream sexual tastes.
I highly recommend this movie.  I found it on cable and got sucked in and couldn't look away.  Really fantastic.

This movie is awesome. It is one of (in my opinion) Liam Neeson's best, and i love Luc Besson whether he writes or directs. His movies (The Fifth Element, From Paris with Love, The Transporter movies, Le Femme Nikita, The Professional, The Big Blue) are one's that i love to watch over and over.
 I only wish there were a lot more of Bryan Mills in the world so they could take out more of these scumbags who kidnap these girls, drug them up and have them turned into prostitutes, and once these girls are of no use to them anymore they throw them away like a piece of trash. All mothers and fathers of daughters need to watch this movie. I would never allow my 17 year old daughter to go alone with her friend and visit a country she doesn't know much about. I am just angered that this is still going on, human trafficking needs to be something of the past. Even in the United States we have human trafficking and this movie just opens peoples eyes to this disgusting trade. If i had the skills and training that Bryan Mills did, i would do the same thing for my child that he did for his.

**Brief Review**

I have loved watching Liam Neeson for some years now.  The man just makes great movies.  Hell, even 'Darkman' is pretty decent.  But he really SHINES in this feature.

**Movie Details/Some Spoilers Ahead**

The film centers around ex-CIA agent Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson).  A divorced man trying desperately to form a closer relationship with his daughter.  He ex-wife Lenore (Famke Janssen) has long remarried, to a filthy rich man, and is not that worried about Neeson getting close to his daughter.

Well summer comes and Neeson's daughter desperately wants to go to Paris, to "study", yeah right...  Neeson must sign a parental consent form for her to leave the country unattended by an adult.  After much goading from Lenore and his daughter he relents.  He soon discovers though that she is actually going to Paris with her friend to follow the band U2 (or maybe it was Blink 182) around Europe.  He is furious about being deceived.

Neeson has been around to say the least and knows how dangerous the world actually is.  Well, his daughter is no more than 10 minutes off the plane in Paris when she and her friend are "marked" by some flesh peddlers.  These monsters steal women, and auction them off into sexual slavery.  Sad to say this is REAL, and something that the international police forces are trying to desperately combat.

As you probably have seen on the movie's trailer, Neeson is on the phone with his daughter when she is kidnapped.  And as you've seen off the commercials "he has a particular set of skills...".  He's a badass to say the least.

In no time at all Liam's on a plane to Paris ready to kill anyone who is between him and his daughter...

--Summing Up--

This film is HIGH on the action scale.  It is a tad slow for like the first 15 minutes, but after that never stops.  Plus the acting is superb.  Forget 'Ransom' with Mel Gibson, 'Taken' is the film to see.

There are very few people who have not seen this movie.  But if you are amoung the few who missed it, definitely check this out.

Is this worth buying.  ABSOLUTELY YES!!!  This is a re-watch times 10.  I have personally watched it apx 3 times, and will no doubt watch it again soon.  In fact just typing this review I am getting the urge to get my copy out and pop it into my aging DVD player.

Well, that's my 3 cents worth on this movie.  Wait, holy crap there's someone in my house, help me Liam!!!

A retired CIA agent lets his ex-wife twist his arm into letting their daughter round all over Europe.  He warned them of the possible and we would not have a movie if the possible did not happen. Yep the daughter was abducted by a ruthless cabal or two to serve in an unsavory capacity.

"Let her go and you won't die." Now how many movies have we heard that in? Well a lot. But Liam Neeson can run with the best of them. He fights the odds and so-called friends to shoot, drive, stab, and what not his way through Sleaze Town and more.

Will he succeed? Will we have fun kibitzing? Why do you find yourself sweating? Oh no you're going to watch it again aren't you?

Supposedly based on a similar event, however if you have to create a middle eastern shiekh, at least cast someone without a name like "Raman" which happens to be a south indian name/surname. Worth a rental but that's it...acting was horrendous in parts.

This was a highly intertaining movie with great photography. The fight scenes were excellent and taken moved at a fast pace with an interesting story, tight script, tight direction, tight acting. This IS a 5 star film if you like a good story that propells the action. I will always tell it like I see it.....Good or bad.
Scott M

Believable, semi-logical, and well paced. Although it takes it to the extreme, people lack the patience and determination to think through scenarios and take into account multiple variables before acting.

Too often we act on emotions and don't care about possible consequences.

Life is not simply a random bag of occurrences. The eventual end comes from the decisions we make along the way. We can  change things if we see and plan.

This movie is pretty mild after having seen Hostel and its horrid sequel. It is also a much better movie. I hated the gore in Hostel. Taken was much more serious. Unfortunately, despite the good message it could have had, it was full of too many impossible situations. But in any case, I am glad I didn't see any of these three movies before going to Europe on my own at the age of 22.

The father (the former spy) is concerned about his daughter going to Paris. Understandable. He seemed a little over-protective. But he was totally balanced out by the mother who was completely unconcerned about anything and went so far as to help the daughter lie about her plans! "She just couldn't tell him the truth," the poor girl. So museums aren't for everybody. Personally I find sculptures and ancient relics much more interesting than paintings. But I must ask: why would ANYONE travel to a foreign country just to pick up the first hot guy they see and follow a rock band around and go to parties and do other things they could just do at home? Oh yeah, ditzy teenagers.

Well, lo and behold, the daughter gets kidnapped, just like the father feared. And she happened to be on the phone with her father at the time. How lucky that he could record the incident! The movie wasn't bad up until this point but shortly afterward all the unbelievable things started to happen. Suspension of disbelief is one thing. But the guy was a former spy, not Superman.

*SPOILER ALERT*
The father goes to two different places where they are holding girls to turn into sex slaves. Naturally his daughter is not in either. He kills everyone he comes across and never gets one little scratch. Then he starts attacking everyone in his path just to get by them. He shoots this one guy's innocent wife just to get him to talk. He goes on this crazy car chase down the wrong side of the highway. Yeah, risk the lives of another innocent 50 people just to save one. Sorry, that's just wrong. Finally he finds his daughter. She wasn't at the other places because she was one of the special ones who was being sold to an individual buyer. Not just that, but they were "saving the best for last." Gee, what are the odds? Why, exactly? Well, she's American, and speaks English and French. Come on, she wasn't even that pretty. I think he didn't find her until the third place he looked because they needed to make the movie longer. Anyway, they capture the father. But even with his hands tied up, he manages to kill another ten bad guys. Yep, a Superman. So a little more drama, and then they come home, and all of a sudden he has his arm in a cast, even though he killed like 60 people without ever getting a scratch. This could have been a much more interesting story, if only it had been better executed. Or if it had been a superhero movie.
Great movie. The directors cut version is better, I say that because it has a little more revenge in it. This movie has some of the best lines ever spoken.

Liam Neeson..is a superb actor. There is no debate. FACT. But seriously, even the most well trained 'security" agent simply cannot ON HIS OWN, defeat an entire entourage of thugs. Would have been a little more realisiic if he had a partner working with him. I also notice a similiarity in this characters actions and kn owledge as a direct origin of the PERSON OF INTEREST lead character. There are a lot of things wrong in this film. the family he "loves" and is "saving" (his wife and daughter) are so spoiled you almos twant them to FEEL some pain of the real world. Very little information is given in this VERY brief 92 minute film of the true nature , organizational skills, methods, and sale destination of girls. Seems a very generic trip to the internet for 'facts. I personally know some young women overseas in Ukraine, latvia, who were trafficked last year. I even had a connection who COULD have helped but he swares "no such thing occured". The reality is scary, the film is actually fairly  UNscary byut the ACTION is TOP NOTCH. And that';s about all this has to offer. Forget deep emotions or political statements--this is a Super hero Film. Not a bad one.

An urban legend comes to life!  Young girls (and boys) should watch this as a precautionary tale to anyone who is going to travel abroad or domestic, or when you meet a stranger here or there.

Liam Neeson plays a semi absentee father who has been working as a highly trained operative on missions around the world.  His time away from home cost him his marriage, now his teenage daughter has asked through his ex wife to take a trip to Europe.  At first she tells him that they will be going to museums and doing touristy things, but he finds just before she leaves that they are really going to travel across Europe to see U2 on the European leg of their tour.  Reluctanly, he agrees (even though he is angry that his daughter and his ex wife lied about it to him) and signs the papers to allow her to travel.  In typical law enforcement manner, Liam demands that his daughter call and let him know where she is at all times.  His daughter and her friend, however, being the stereotypical flaky teenagers they are, say hello to a random stranger they meet at the airport.  He seems friendly enough, offers to share a cab to their destination, then gets their phone number.  Little do they know they are being lured into a trap.  And what a trap it is!  In a panic, his daughter tells her father on the phone that they are being kidnapped.  Liam immediately jumps onto a plane and heads to Paris to track his daughter down from the sex slavery ring she has been lured into.

The older I get, the more I see the signifigance of a story like that.  Having traveled abroad and been hassled and hustled by many a suave European man, be cautious.  You never know who is going to take you for a ride.  They may not be pulling you into sex slavery, but they are looking for something else.  And it also happens right here in the US, in your own backyard.  I have several friends in law enforcement, they question everything and anything I do.  "DO you know that man you were talking to over there?" "Yes, I know him from ___".  Paranoid?  It has merit.  A stranger is not just a friend you haven't met, you must be very careful with people with what you do and say, because you simply do not know what others are capable of or what they are after.  As a kid, you do not believe that people will treat you like a piece of meat, but they will.  Just wait until it happens to you.

Some words of criticism?  It was a bit hoaky that Liam would actually find his daughter with all the hoops he had to jump through.  Granted, he plays a spy who had access to certain information that the average person would not otherwise.  But, after all, this is entertainment about a not so pleasent subject.

Be warned, kids, the world is a crazy and dangerous place.  Be tough, street smart, and keep up a shield.  You will need it.

I watched this movie the other day at my friend's house and saw nothing that was extended on it other than maybe 2-3 seconds of the opening scene where they show a picture of his daughter on a pony and that was it, this is a joke to release a great movie such as this and call it extended cut, i gave the 5 stars for the film not the version. Save your money if you have the regular version then stick with it if not then i guess you can pick this one but once again there's nothing in there that you'll be missing.

TAKEN is a great movie to watch with your teenaged daughter. I have tried for a very long time to make my child understand that sexual slavery is alive and well so I don't have to worry *as much* that she will let herself get into a precarious situation. I've recounted numerous real-life human trafficking cases to her, went through the Polaris Project's website with her, showed her FBI statistics which show that selling girls is the 2nd most profitable criminal enterprise in the world (drugs is #1,) and still felt like I was talking to a brick wall. All I got in return were eye-rolls and infamous, I-am-the-invulnerable-teenager quotes like, "Mom, you worry too much. I'm not stupid and that is soooo not gonna happen to me!" Then we watched TAKEN... finally, finally, finally she is starting to get it!! This movie does an excellent job of showing how quickly traffickers work and how slick they are with little girls. It conveys the terror a girl is engulfed with when she's kidnapped, how easy it is to be kidnapped, the horrible sexual and physical abuse the victim suffers (without actually showing it,) and how the average little girl would never be found because they don't have a former spy (Liam Neeson) for a parent. After watching TAKEN my daughter's entire attitude has changed for the better. She is learning martial arts, staying cognizant of her surroundings, and is also more interested in the real-life cases she didn't want to hear about before. (An excellent non-fiction book to give your teenager to read after viewing this movie is The Slave Next Door: Human Trafficking and Slavery in America Today, With a New Preface - actually, everyone should read it.) For those not interested in a mom's perspective and are reading reviews for the cinematic experience, TAKEN is a fast-paced thriller that snags your attention and keeps it the whole way through. The only truly unbelievable character in the movie is the mother, Liam Neeson's ex-wife. She's one of those TSTL (Too Stupid To Live) characters that thinks more like a know-it-all 16-year-old girl than a mature, grown woman. Luckily, she's just a side character and not in much of the movie overall. 5 stars! Definitely worth owning

I am in love with this movie! <3 It is one of my favorites. Liam Neeson does a fantastic performance. A man who doesn't stop until he gets what he came for. I just can't wait for the second part to come out this year! =D

I'm not a big fan of action movies. They tend to focus on violence and killing as many people as possible in the most original ways, but a select few have more depth. Taken falls into the latter category.

Why is it so good?

If you had told me that a 56-year-old actor would make one of the best action movies I've ever seen, I would have laughed and thought how bad Roger Moore's version of James Bond was in A View to a Kill and Octopussy. Action movies often feature actors who look the part, but who can't really act. Arnold Schwarzenegger springs to mind. Liam Neeson changes all that with this one performance. He doesn't look like he could take on the world, but his acting ability is so good that he convinces you that he's capable of everything he does in the movie.

Bryan Mills (Neeson) used to work for the government as a CIA operative. He still associates with friends from his previous job, but he's given up that career in an attempt to get closer to his daughter, Kim (Maggie Grace). She lives with his ex-wife, Lenore (Famke Janssen), and her rich stepfather. When Mills takes Kim a thoughtful gift on her seventeenth birthday, her stepfather gives her a horse. Mills doesn't seem to have a chance of winning her respect. What's more, Lenore apparently hates him.

Mills is given another chance to make a connection with Kim when she asks him to sign a consent form so that she can leave the country for a vacation. As she's 17, she needs the permission of both parents. Mills isn't happy about the idea. He's seen a lot of criminal activity in his former line of work and understands the dangers involved. Is he just being paranoid? His dire warnings seem exaggerated, but we soon see that they are justified.

Kim goes to Paris with her 19-year-old friend and trusts everyone she meets. The day she arrives, an Albanian gang take her and her friend captive. We learn that they intend to control her through drugs and turn her into a prostitute, or perhaps even sell her to a willing buyer.

Perhaps the best moment in the movie is when Mills talks to Kim's captor on her phone:

"I don't know who you are. I don't know what you want. If you are looking for ransom, I can tell you I don't have money. But what I do have are a very particular set of skills; skills I have acquired over a very long career. Skills that make me a nightmare for people like you. If you let my daughter go now, that'll be the end of it. I will not look for you, I will not pursue you. But if you don't, I will look for you, I will find you, and I will kill you."

He says it with absolute conviction.

I won't give away any more of the story. That setup takes around 25 minutes. If I have done a good job, perhaps you can understand why Taken is different. Mills is real. We understand his motives for giving up his job. When Kim is taken, we start to see some of the skills he claims to possess.

If she was your daughter, how would you react? What if you had the requisite skills to seek her out yourself? Is there anything you wouldn't do to save her?

Director Pierre Morel doesn't waste a single minute. At 93 minutes, the movie is lean and the action rarely allows us time to breathe once Mills kicks into action. He's a relentless killing machine, but, unlike most action heroes, his abilities seem authentic. To make things seem even more urgent, we experience everything from his point of view. Expect to see plenty of fast cuts during chase scenes, just as you would in The Bourne Trilogy.

It's easy to root for Mills because of the strong characterization. Neeson excels in this role and carries the movie throughout. I wonder if we'll start to see other good actors cast in action roles as a result? Taken is an enjoyable thrill ride with almost endless replay value.
This is an action feel good movie. Liam Neeson shows his range by playing a tough guy that can handle himself with the best of them - Cruise, Damon, Eastwood.
Though this is fiction, the Sex Slavery market is real.  All young ladies traveling abroad should see this movie to be made aware that these things DO happen.

"They kidnapped my daughter!" I can't remember how many action movies start that way, including flicks with Bruce Willis, Steven Segal, Chuck Norris, and just about anyone else you could name. It's one of the most heavily used jumping-off points for getting the story going. So, since the basic premise is so well worn, what really matters is where the movie jumps to.

Neeson, with hair color not quite matching the lines in his face, does a great job as the wrong guy to mess with. He pounds his way through the seamy side of Paris with grim inexorability, from its grubby underbelly to the highest ranks of society and authority. As you might expect, the bodies of bad guys stack like cordwood. For all that violence, there's remarkably little visible bloodshed, but one or two moments seemed gratuitous. (Was that 'flesh wound' really necessary?)

If you're looking for a macho fantasy of righteous wrath, carried out by an implacable and seemingly indestructible loner, you came to the right place. You'll have to suspend disbelief for a while, but this movie's suspense repays the effort.

-- wiredweird, reviewing the release to theaters

We bought this movie with the intent of showing it to our young daughters, who are full of energy and want to travel the world. It has hepled us forwarned them that everyone is not friendly, and to be aware of malicious individuals.

First of all it's a compelling action flick, albeit ridiculously unrealistic.  This movie portrays Dad as the Super-Hero to his daughter:  he's all-knowing, all-powerful, completely bullet-proof and one who beats the crap out of her many kidnappers.  I get the feeling that the Hollywood industry is chock full of divorced Dads who feel like failures to their children, and this movie is kind of an over-the-top fantasy to compensate.  OR the producers are targeting this film to middle-age Dads who feel inadequate, and/or the children who fantasize about having an all-powerfull protective father.  At any rate, this action fantasy certainly hits the psychological mark for the intended audience.  Liam Neeson is a perfect selection to portray the 50ish former CIA action guy who rescues his daughter from a ring of Albanian kidnappers and traffickers in young prostitutes, in France.  He's smart as well as tough, basically is invincible, beats up any number of pathetic bad guys, shoots a bunch more like Rambo, and doesn't get a scratch.  But, really, there's too much of this psychological "Father Figure Worship" going on here.  Even how the movie starts out, with Neesom hired to be a bodyguard to some cute young female pop singer.  She gives him attitude ("the Old Guy" syndrome), then he saves her from a psychopathic fan, and of course she worships him.  What older guy wouldn't want to be idolized by a young, famous, attractive female?  So it starts out a little bit cheesy in that respect.  But this initial episode is just a forerunner to the real action when SUPERMAN DAD starts kicking Bad-guy butt!

The plot then moves on to the worldly, divorced Dad telling his 18-19YO girl (on a trip to France OK'ed by her Mother, travelling with a stupid partying friend) to be careful.  Under the influence from her dumb (and doomed) friend, she's not, and they get taken virtually seconds after they get off the plane.  A truly compelling scene is when she calls Dad (who's living in the US) on the cell from Paris, hiding under the bed as the Albanians enter their apartment, and then you hear a scream, a commotion, and some thug with a thick accent taunts Dad over the phone (this will come back to haunt the thug!).  As the cliche goes, it's "Every Parent's Worst Nightmare!"

Superman Dad springs into action and tracks her down with a number of ingeneous moves, getting himself targeted by the French police in the process.  So Neeson's character has to track her trail through all of Paris while beating and killing many bad guys in the process, all the while avoiding the French police.  I.e. typical Hollywood super-spy stuff.  It REALLY taps into one's psyche: if YOUR daughter were kidnapped, could you save her with such ruthless and efficient aplomb?  Not a chance!  But our hero Liam Neeson can!  It is a good ride if you totally suspend your disbelief.

Now let's compare to REALITY for a second: the ultra-dangerous world South of our border where Mexico is now rated the WORST country in the world for kidnapping!  Literally hundreds of people a year get taken there, and how many of them get saved by their parents or even by the Law??  Not many.  Even Americans are getting kidnapped, because the cartels know that they can squeeze their family for $$$ before they kill them.  (Bet you didn't know this -- our pathetic media don't want to tell you for some reason!!!) It's a horrible scene.  I really wish that we could turn 100 Liam Neesons loose in Mexico to wipe out all the criminal murderers, torturers and kidnappers.  Let's dream on!  So to stoke your own revenge fantasies, all out there who have some deep emotional feelings about this sort of Evil (and kidnapping is truly Evil) should watch "Taken" and maybe you'll feel more inspired and less cynical about it than I do.

Taken is one of those action packed movies that makes you not want to blink, for fear that you might miss something. Liam Neeson is a wonderful actor; hardcore, and ruthless without even batting an eye when necessary, yet looks suave and innocent, until rubbed the wrong way. It gave the viewer action, suspense, and made ever minute well worth watching. While I by no means condone killing; Mr. Neeson actually made it interesting to watch. Taken, has definitely made it to my favorite movies of all time list. I highly recommend this movie, and I give it 5 stars.

You really need to watch this flick. Action packed for sure. And every one that is killed in the movie deserves it big time. I just loved the story and Liam was excellent in this movie. The daughter was a tad on the nerdy side for my liking but did a good job in the acting department. One of my all time favorite movies,and thats saying some ting for me. I give it 5 stars and then some.
I have never wanted to see bad guys get killed so badly in my life. A great movie. I watched it twice in two days.
Much more graphic and hard-ass than the States version. It took me a while to find it after seeing it online, but well worth the hunt.

The movie doesn't take long to start putting the viewer on the edge of their seat. Right away I knew something bad was goign to happen. Daughter goes on european trip with friends, first time away from home, dad is very leery about letting daughter out of his sight worried about all of the horrible things he knows can happen to young girls... and his concerns come to fruition when she is abducted. Great keep you on the edge of your seat type of movie with lots of action and intrigue. Worth the watch.

I wish I could say that the plot of this film is contrived, unrealistic and would never actually happen to anyone in real-life. I really do wish that were the case.  Unfortunately, the opposite is true:  the plotline is about as accurate to what happens as a plotline can possibly be.  It sheds a light on a crisis of growing proportion in the world, yet one that gets all too little exposure:  human trafficking.

Bryan (Liam Neeson) is an ex CIA spook whose daughter is ambushed / kidnapped while on a trip to Paris.  Luckily for her (and unluckily for her captors!), his skills give him an unexpected advantage in tracking down the thugs who took her from him.  Bryan takes on the HT network with all the grace of a wrecking ball ramming into a 100 year old building!

Kidnapping for ransom is something that tends to only happen to the wealthy.  After all, kidnappers who are after $$ have little incentive to kidnap people who are of a modest financial worth.  Human trafficking, on the other hand, is an entirely different animal.  It can happen to anyone, anytime, as selling the person to a 3rd party is the objective, rather than selling the individual back to their family / friends.

For this reason, this movie is a must-see as it sheds a much needed light on an all too frequent egregious practice.  It points out how the culprits operate in preying on "soft targets" who are far from home.  I can honestly say that viewing this movie could actually save lives in the "real" world in which we live.

I had very high hopes going into Taken, mainly because I think Liam Neeson is an amazing actor and has a reputation of participating in good movies (until recently - Clash of the Titans and possibly The A-Team). The first half-hour of the film was very engaging and the scene of the daughter's capture was intense. It stayed fairly intense for the rest of the movie, but my interest slowly declined from there, mainly because of the character progression of Neeson. Again, I will do my best not to spoil the movie for those who still have not seen it. In the beginning, Neeson is a very likable lead character. He portrays a credible father through the entire movie, there is no question about that. The problem arises when Neeson's daughter is taken and he assumes his role as ex-spy. Neeson throws away the good-natured, fatherly persona and becomes a violent James Bond-like figure, killing anyone and everyone that he sees. He almost becomes the bad guy in the film, lacking the qualities that set him apart from his enemies; basically becoming a mindless killing machine, especially by the end of the film. You still get the feeling that he'd do anything to get his daughter back, but you begin to wonder at what price. It's a pretty vengeful movie. **Spoiler Alert** The movie ends pretty quickly. Neeson finds where his daughter is, bursts in, guns blazing, and kills everyone in a matter of minutes. The thing that bothered me the most about this film is after Neeson gets his daughter back. They return to America and suddenly everything is back to normal and its like the whole thing never happened. Everyone's happy and wonderful and untraumatized. Sure, the daughter has a better relationship with her father, but other than that, nothing has changed from the beginning of the movie. I hated that! Annoyed the heck out of me. It's like they could have cut out everything in-between and you still would have had the same ending. Grrr.. never do that; completely takes away anything to be gained from the film. As far as questionable content: **Spoiler Alert** - The daughter is part of a large group of women that are being sold as sex slaves to foreign men, so you can imagine what the women are all wearing, or almost not wearing, during the bidding scene. There are a couple other scenes that deal with this content that are a bit risky. **Non-Spoiler Alert** - The movie is a fairly violent film. Lots of shooting and hand-to-hand-to-knife combat stuff going on. So, be ready to see violence. There is some profanity, but no "F"-bomb. Because of the nature of the theft of the daughter, there are sexual references. [...]
The video was received in a timely manner for Christmas.  It was well packaged and was great for a gift.

The next time your little darlings wants to travel for Spring Break sit their little tokhes down to watch this movie, then have them write a 5 page report on human trafficking and guaranteed they will not want to leave their rooms until they are 30. You, as a parent, might not sleep for the next 20 years, but certainly, you will see the world from a different more paranoid perspective and will hold on to those little honeys with all your fingers and all your claws.

Liam Neeson plays Bryan Mills a retired CIA agent that has recently retired and moved to Los Angeles in hopes of building a better relationship with his daughter. Ex-wife and daughter ambush and guilt Bryan into signing the papers that will allow their daughter to leave the country and soon Kim and her friend Amanda are jetting off to Paris only to be befriended by an Albanian gang of human traffickers.

The intensity is nonstop and the perils that both Bryan and his daughter have to face leave your heart and stomach somewhere in the middle of your throat.

This movie is not for the squeamish. There are brutal fight scenes and the subject matter might be too much for some to handle, but over all, this is a very good movie. Liam Neeson does a remarkable job in portraying both the professionally trained killer and the deeply loving and scared father.

This is a movie not to be missed.

Great movie! Lots of action, thrills, and suspense. I highly recommend this film to anyone who likes action movies. Liam Neeson is excellent in the role. Best line," I don't have money, but what I do have are a special set of skills that make me a nightmare for people like you."  So grab the popcorn and settle in for the ride!!

Liam Neeson probably made this film for the money, though it does reaffirm that he can be a highly credible action star. But the movie itself is deeply silly and wholly unworthy of Neeson's talent and dignity. As supposedly a highly experienced government covert operative Neeson's character's skills seem to be restricted to knuckleheaded violence when a moment's pause may deliver better results.

The movie could therefore be accused of ignoring its own internal logic: how this highly trained professional uses his specialist skills to rescue his kidnapped daughter... apart from the fact that it really has no logic other than seeking an excuse to set up the next fight.

Some effort on reseach and writing could have produced a decent thriller out of the idea behind this film. As it stands the movie is probably best watched after three beers on a Saturday night with all critical faculties suspended. To be fair, in these circumstances, it passes the time entertainingly.

This DVD was shipped quickly and packaged well so arrived undamaged. This movie is very intense and not appropriate for children but a great action movie that highlights a serious problem. You will get engrossed in the story and recognize scary realities without feeling like you are watching a documentary.
This is one of my favorite movies, so I sent it to a friend for her birthday.  I hope she enjoys it as much as I do.
The Taken (Single-Disc Extended Edition) DVD came very quickly and it was in perfect condition. It was exactly what I was looking for. I am happy with my purchase.

I am usually a really big Liam Neeson fan and when I first bought this movie I wasn't sure if I would enjoy the story line but I have to admit that I was very pleased. He portrays an extremely loving father whose daughter is "taken" while on vacation. Needless to say, I was captured within the first few minutes...made for a good movie during movie night for our family.

Taken is an action flick that's both efficient and absurd, and so it's often entertaining -- but only up to a point. The film stars Liam Neeson as a retired CIA agent who learns his daughter has been abducted in Paris; upon receiving a frantic phone call from her, he tracks her down -- and finds himself on the trail of a massive criminal enterprise. Taken is a sprightly piece of work, and Neeson is compelling in the lead role, but the film is weighted down by contrivances and leaps in logic.

I have always liked Liam in every movie I have seen of his. But I did have reservations about him pulling a "John Clark" out of his fanny after his stelar preformance in Love Actually. HOLY COW! I was blown away by the whole movie.

It was real on a level that most action movies with their jacked-up, every moment a crowd pleaser, and someone getting blown up or shot up. Don't get me wrong, I do like those movies with the rest of the lemmings, but have been jonsing for some intelegance as well. Taken was the perfect blend of thinking and action + a raw look at the white slave trade in some parts of the world. I got chills just watching what the girls had to go through and was (again) blown away by his ability to show the vulnerability of the dad side of his character as well as the emotional void of the assassin.

I really wish they used Liam for the upcomming movie "one shot". He was my ideal for Jack Reacher... oh well, you can't have everything.

Very emotional and action packed. Liam Nelson is the new action star. Movie is fast paced and it keeps your attention. Wish ending had a more dynamic interaction with Liam character and the exam wife.

SPOILERS:
I did like this movie, but I found it too formulaic for my tastes. It basically went like this:
1. Painstakingly explain to the audience our hero's penchant for attention to detail and love for his daughter
2. Go on mini-mission to foreshadow Bryan's (Liam's) ability for kicking butt.
3. Kidnap daughter and daughter's friend (whose sole purpose in the movie--btw--is to die)
4. Go rescue daughter

Items 3 and 4 are the meat of movie and what give it its entertainment value...but the road you take to get there is so long and boring. For instance, there is a scene in the beginning where Bryan carefully picks out an inexpensive present for his daughter and meticulously wraps it. The director clearly demonstrates Bryan's love for his daughter, lack of funds and attention to detail with this one scene. That's enough for us to get the gist, but now we have to experience a BBQ with his buddies who regurgitate what we already know...and badger him into a small mission so he can get some money. It was 20 minutes of the movie that could have been completely removed. Liam MAKES this movie. He is so great! Without him, this flick would've gone straight to video.

A weapon, by simple definition, is a tool used to protect one's self or others from harm.  The hero in this story is a living, breathing weapon who, in his own words, was a 'preventor' when he worked for the government in an obviously highly skilled special ops unit once the action starts.

The cost for his dedication and diligence was his family.  His wife left him and took their daughter, marrying a very wealthy business man who raises up his daughter as his little princess while the ex wife clearly allows her bitterness to show to their daughter.

So, when Neeson's character 'retires' to civilian life, all he has is a home movie of his daughter's last birthday under his roof, a single digit birthday where she gives a happy, adoring smile into the camera to show off her missing front tooth and blows out the candle on her birthday cake.  He has a single photo album in which he has a single photo from each of his daughter's subsequent birthdays until this one, her seventeenth.

He is a man who has the time to consider everything he does with purpose when it comes to his daughter and her happiness.  He keeps his distance from the ex and the new husband, but makes an effort to maintain a pleasant relationship with the man who is helping to raise his daughter in his stead. He obviously loves his daughter and she loves him, managing well enough not allow her mother's bitterness to cloud her relationship with her father, but as any teen would, she does use her mother's feelings to her advantage as we soon see.

As you watch the first few moments of the movie you get a picture of how lonely this man is, how much he sacrificed and while he does not regret that sacrifice, he does wish that he knew how to make things better, to re-establish a relationship with his daughter when she is on the cusp of adulthood and spreading her wings.

And her first act of spreading those wings is to go to Paris with her best friend to stay at the friend's cousin's home.  Now, because Neesom's character knows how ugly the real world is, he's not on board with this, especially with the way daughter and mom spring it on him the day after her birthday.  Because she is underrage they need his signature on paperwork to allow her to travel out of the country, and if Daddy doesn't approve, she can't go, so little missy turns on the water works and Daddy caves.  Unfortunately, when they arrive at the airport, he discovers that his daughter isn't going over to Paris for a simple vacation but they're following a band across Europe to attend all their concerts.

Angry at being lied to and against his better judgment, he allows his daughter to go on the trip and within an hour of the girls arriving at their destination, they are kidnapped.

His daughter happened to be away from the action with it first starts and she's on her cell phone with him, relaying what she's seeing through the window as her friend is being physically hauled out of the apartment.  His training kicks in and he's now a father and a highly trained special ops soldier and while he's telling his daughter what he needs to know in real time, he also has to tell her that there isn't going to be any way to stop her kidnapping.

The look on his face when he hears his daughter screaming for him makes you feel that moment right in the pit of your stomach and when the kidnapper picks up the cell phone after they take his daughter, he spells it out for them loud and clear:  I don't have money but I have a specific skill set.  You let my daughter go or I will hunt you down and kill you.

The bad guys think he's joking or blustering but he is serious and with the help of his old team and resources, he's on the move, heading to Paris and he starts with the creep at the airport who targeted the girls for the crew to kidnap and works his way up the foodchain.

He's been told his clock is 96 hours before he'll never be able to find his daughter and he's not wasting a second of that time playing nice or taking prisoners.  His daughter has been sold into a prostitution ring and he's not letting anyone who had any involvement in the organization off the hook.  He doesn't stop, he doesn't negotiate, he doesn't quibble, he's hunting for his daughter and every time another truly sleazy bad guy bites the dust you can't help but cheer for him.

The uncut version vs. the theatrical version is superior only in that you see him serving out the punishment these pigs deserve and it gives you a certain sense of satisfaction and justice that they don't prevail this time and they won't get a chance to victimize anyone else.

While there is a good deal of violence, it's not gory like a horror film, and there is alot of high intensity action that culminates in the rescue that you're holding your breath for.

It's a thrill ride and entertaining but it also has some clear lessons about the consequences of the choices we make.
Really a good movie.  Scary that there are people out there like this, but there are.  Wont' say too much, but it's a good action movie!

I knew the core plot of this movie. Yet when I watched I was drawn in completely. The action is sudden, raw and real - it reminded me of The Bourne Identity. "Quickly! There's no time!" Review must start now!

Don't bother buying this version of the DVD as all you get is two versions of the movie--the theatrical release and unrated version. There are zero extras.

Having said that it's an entertaining thriller in which Mel Gibson...oops, I thought ALL movies where the dad gets angry and seeks revenge as a one-man team by himself starred Mel...it's Liam Neeson in this one.

Huge plot holes and improbable one man vs. everyone where (it's Hollywood, 'natch) all he suffers is a hurt wing in the entire movie but takes out approximately 9,555 Albanian (yes, Albanian!) criminals in Paris (yes, set that movie in a foreign locale to boost that overseas box office).

The dumbest plot device (or non-device) is the fact we are introduced to his three other ex-CIA buddies who now work security for a pop singer. Now, to me, rather than going it alone to Paris given he has only 96 hours to save his daughter from a life of white slavery, he only enlists one guy to do some research on the criminals who may be involved with the kidnapping of his daughter. You don't think these guys would take 96 hours out of their lives to help their buddy, if asked?

I just didn't get that. Why introduce these guys as his friends and have them bond at a backyard barbecue then on a job working security, then say bye bye. Did they not have enough in the budget to pay them all to fly to Paris?

Anyway, there are some cringe-inducing drugged out scenes of horror as young girls are forced into prostitution so fair warning those who don't dig needles, disgusting room conditions and the whole world of human trafficking. Other than that plenty of bad guy fu, explosions-a-go-go and all around non-stop action.

Loved the soft spoken quiet confidence he manifests thru out the film. Very matter of fact kind of strength that doesn't need to boast. Just gets the job done. I am adding this along with "the unknown" to my "I have a crush on Liam" collection.
The movie plays great! Was just as described. No scratches and in great condition. Great action flick! Would recommend to many!
I am very happy with my product.  I received it earlier than I had expected and the product was in the condition that had been promised.

I was so impressed by the condition of this movie and it came directly to my home which saved me from having to find someone to come and get me since I am incapacitated due to surgery. Hightly recommended.

Liam Neeson is a government retiree who has devoted his life to his work. His ex-wife has since devoted herself to a new husband, and now Neeson attempts to reconnect to his teenage daughter. We get a glimpse of his prior life when former colleagues coax him into a security detail for protecting a pop star. With cat-like reflexes and skill he quickly dispatches an attacker and gets his star to safety.

Cynical about the world he worked in, Neeson is pressured by his daughter and ex to allow the girl to take a chaperone-free trip to the City of Lights. He is torn between his fear for his daughter's safety and losing a relationship with her by saying no.

The trip soon turns ugly when her daughter sees her friend being abducted from another room. She knows she is next and quickly calls her father on the cell phone he gave her. When the abductors find her she leaves the cell phone on and it is picked up by the abductor. The father offers a carrot and a stick. If they leave his daughter alone, he will forget their crime, otherwise he will find them and kill them. The abductor is foolish enough to say, "good luck!" before he hangs up.

When he arrives in Paris, the action really begins and there is a spike in metropolitan crime with what he does and what he learns.  A father is out to rescue his daughter and there is no time to spare. It leaves him no room for subtlety or diplomatic courtesies. The dialogue is intelligent and fast-paced, and Neeson is always convincing in whatever role he plays. In fact, you even forget the others except for the French inspector.

If you like to see death by Kleenex, where one person dies slowly over the course of the script, this is probably not your cup of tea. "La Chocolat" it is not. However, if you like to see a lot of strangers die violently throughout the movie than hold on to your black belt, because this is right up your alley.

"Taken" should be borrowed or bought and watched. I've even watched it twice.

Take some time for "Taken."

The '08 cinematic release 'Taken' is an exciting, action packed (though somewhat implausble) rescue / revenge film that doesn't let up from beginning to end. Liam Neeson (one of my favorite actors) is sensational as /Bryan Mills, an ex-spy who singlehandedly undertakes a perilous rescue mission to save his estanged daughter who has been kidnapped by a ring of slave traders. He is relentless, fierce, methodical and cold blooded as he dishes out the same level of pain and punishment practiced by those he pursues.

'Taken' is not a film I would suggest for an evening of family entertainment, but if you have a group of guys together who want to see fists flying this is the one.

Action movies are not at the top of my favorite films list, but I have watched this one several times. The storyline of young girls being kidnapped and forced to work as sex slaves is disturbing and sadly all too true, but watching Liam do his best to find his daughter is mesmerizing. Most of the film is set in beautiful Paris and this adds an exotic element and a sharp contrast to the horrendous conditions the girls are forced to live in. Some edge-of-your-seat action scenes keep the story moving at a fast pace and the acting is terrific. The ending does not disappoint.
nice outer packaging but real surprise is inside when its not what is on the cover, for christ sakes check your packages and make accuracy a priority or get out the business

So says the films protagonist Bryan Mills(Liam Neeson)talking to his daughter's kidnapper over the phone. If you like your action straight up,no chasers,then Taken,released in Feb. 2008 and put onto DVD in /09,is THE film for you. Once the action starts,it's a hold-onto-your-seats thrill ride that never lets up.
The plot is pretty straightforward. An ex CIA special agent Bryan Mills is attending his daughter's birthday party. From the get go Mills we see is meticulous in his personal habits,all stemming from his background training. His CIA days are behind him but he still keeps in touch with some of his former close associates. His daughter Kim's(Maggie Grace)mother Lenore(Famke Janssen) has remarried and Bryan's relationship with her is quite strained. When Mills meets with his daughter and ex for lunch,Kim asks for his permission to go to Paris with her girlfriend. He is reluctant and he thinks about it. He eventually comes around and Kim is away,with a few stipulations her dad has made on her.
The two arrive in Paris and head for their rented flat. On the way they meet a nice looking young man who they arrange to attend a party with later on. While the two are unpacking some unknown men enter the apartment and Kim's friend is taken away in a big struggle. Kim has been talking on the phone with her dad and she describes to him in detail what is taking place. Frightened and barely hanging on, all due to her dad's calm demeanor/training,she hides in an adjacent bedroom under a bed. He tells her she will be taken but to leave the phone open as long as she can and,most importantly,he will come for her.
Kim is dragged away as Mills listens. Springing into action he contacts not only her mother but his old associates who offer some technical skills in obtaining background info on the kidnappers. Mills only positive lead is that he has heard the sound of one of the kidnappers. He flies to Paris and clandestinely enters the girls apartment. He tenders the help of an old Paris police detective which leads him nowhere. From the memory card of his daughters smashed telephone he garners a picture of one of her kidnappers. He tracks him down at the airport and just when it seems he has eluded Mills he gets killed by a passing truck.
Mills knows that an Albanian gang,specializing in human trafficking,is the group responsible for taking his daughter. This leads him to a construction site which also houses a brothel run by the gang. He puts a temporary stop to the place by almost completely demolishing the operation but in the process gets a lead in the form of a heavily drugged girl who has his daughters jacket. He takes her to a motel and dries her out and gets the address of the place Kim might be at. He poses as a French policeman there to renegotiate his "fee" to keep quiet about their operations and enters the den of the Albanian traffickers. While there he fingers the man whose voice he heard briefly on the phone and after some further"negotiations", leaves with his man.
Using some plain old fashioned torture,he gleans the info that his daughter is now in the hands of a wealthy Parisian socialite who specializes in the sale of human flesh. Mills attends that function and poses as a waiter serving champagne. While in the small room with a buyer he finally sees his daughter,which he forces the buyer to obtain. While leaving the room to get his daughter(with the buyer in tow)the security there gets the best of him and his is held downstairs to be executed. Before they can do him in he is able to get free and turn the tables. He rushes out after his daughter who is now aboard a yacht owned by a wealthy Sheik. Through a car ride to beat all car rides he tries to catch up to the boat and eventually is able to jump aboard and overcome most of the security with all the usual lightening fast moves he has so far displayed throughout the film. He finally comes face to face with the Sheik holding his daughter at knife point. At the very moment the Sheik is about to negotiate with Mills,Mills shoots him dead with precision aim.
Daughter Kim safely back in his arms,they both fly home.
Famed French writer,director Luc Besson(The Fifth Element)uses a deft hand in his control here. The editing is top notch;no filler and all meat. The action once it starts,is breathtaking to watch as Mills' former "training"/"special skills" are something to behold indeed. Neeson is right in the zone throughout which adds that much more to the believability and intensity of the proceedings. The supporting cast is great and the stunt work wonderful.
Technically is the film has been transferred onto DVD in its original 2:40:1 a/r,and is clear and crisp. This version has both the theatrical and extended cuts of the film. There is commentary,the trailer and a making of featurette. There is however something the buyer should be aware of and it is in the making of the DVD itself. There is a scene where Mills enters the Albanians lair(behind the red door).He presents a card to one of the kidnappers. At that moment there seems to be a layer change and the film briefly stops ans starts. This is a common thing but here the sound actually goes out of sync with the actions/mouths on screen. I have checked this on a couple of players and it does it on both. It's a manufacturers glitch and should have been taken care of but of course these things never are unless the release is successful enough to warrant a future re-release. Gotta love this industry don't you?
All in all a top notch effort by all involved. Neeson is the intense protagonist who you just KNOW is going to get his man,or in this case his daughter. We know the ending before it really gets going but the trick is to sit back and enjoy the ride,and what a ride it is. 4 1/2 stars,recommended viewing.

No.  Judge Dredd is the worst, but TAKEN easily moves into second place.  The writing, editing and acting are all atrocious and manipulative.

The movie starts with a montage of a father flipping through pictures of his daughter as a child, a banal attempt to set up an emotional connection with the viewer, which utterly fails for anyone over the age of about six.  More failed emotional blackmail follows as the father buys a present for his daughter, then takes it to her birthday party (and proceeds to make an ass of himself, to show us how 'tough' he is and will be), while the movie tries to show us the father is the 'good' parent and the mother is a bitch.  Daddy gives the present to his daughter, she loves it, then rich step dad brings out a horsie for the little girl (she is 17).  Spoiled little rich girl drops daddy's present and runs to the horsie.  I almost cried.  No, make that almost retched.  Daughter is going to Paris and Daddy has to sign a form allowing her to travel out of the country?  Really, could this possible be true?  He's opposed but gets emotionally blackmailed into allowing her to go.

To cut to the chase, once in Paris Daddy's little virgin is kidnapped by Albanian sex slavers and Daddy, ex-covert ops superman, goes on a rampage to save her.  The movie, previously attempting, and failing, to set us up to care about these flat, lifeless characters now goes all out into "Die Hard" mode.  Daddy finds daughters hotel room, actually talks to the kidnappers (WTF!) and finds a camera.  He takes the camera to a photo booth, inserts the memory card and instantly finds a pix of daughters kidnapper in a reflection in one of the pix.  How does Daddy know this guy is the kidnapper?  Because Daddy is SUPER SPY!  This is the first of many unbelievable plot contrivances that take up the entire rest of the movie.  Daddy now goes to the airport, finds the guy (who is wearing the exact same highly recognizable clothing) and proceeds to chase him through the streets outside of the airport, causing massive vehicular mayhem the whole time.  Bad guy gets away, only to stand on a highway and get smashed by a truck.  No Paris police or airport security seem to care that Daddy is causing dozens of car wrecks while doing this as the movie simplistically moves us on to the next scene without any problems for Daddy, not even a traffic ticket.

A couple of scenes move us forward, one in which Daddy talks to a buddy who just 'happens to know' that it is Albanians who are totally in charge of kidnapping beautiful girls for sex slaves in Paris.  He then meets up with an old French police buddy who gives him some additional info to move the plot forward a bit.  Since Daddy has lost his source to find the Albanians (got smashed by a truck) he goes to a Rue where streetwalkers hang out and talks to one of the girls.  He acts like an a** and of course one of the Albanians is watching, walks up to Daddy to get rid of him.  Daddy places a wireless bug on bad guy (he has an Albanian interpreter with him) and finds out where the bad guys hang out.  Daddy goes to a construction site where he finds the bad guys selling girls to the construction workers.  His daughter isn't one of them so he goes on his first rampage, killing dozens in a stupid and unbelievable car chase, once again with no Paris police caring at all that their city is being shot up.  At one point he is in a car with a girl he taken with him.  A bad guy car is right next to them and the bad guys are firing automatic weapons directly into Daddy's car.  Is Daddy or the girl hurt?  Noooo!!!  Why?  Where did all the bullets go?  Who knows?  Who cares?

Moving forward a bit, Daddy once agains finds another bad guy hideout (how?  don't know and don't care) and presents himself as a Paris detective.  Does Daddy speak French?  Noooo!!!  Do the bad guys speak English?  Yesss!!!!  Does anyone care?  Noooo!!!!  Daddy proceeds to blow away all these bad guys, after recognizing the voice of one of the bad guys as the same person he spoke with on the phone.  Really?  Who cares anymore.  Stupid plot contrivance abound.

Daddy now finds out his old Paris police buddy is protecting the bad guys (another unbelievable plot contrivance) and goes the detectives house to confront him.  Detective refuses to help (he needs the money the bad guys pay him) so Daddy shoots the wife (sample line: "It's only a flesh wound") to get the cop to talk.  Of course, the cop's two kids don't run out to see what happened when their mother was shot, they are asleep in bed.  The copy tells Daddy where to go next.  After all, the plot is so thin and stupid that someone is always telling Daddy exactly where to go, or he figures it out himself somehow.

Daddy next goes to a fancy dress ball/party where he once again presents himself with his fake French Police ID, which of course totally gets him instantly into the party without him speaking a word of, um, what is it?  Oh yeah, French.  Daddy spots the bad guy.  How does he know that this one guy in a tux out of hundreds of guys in tuxes is the bad one?  Who cares!  He knows, he just knows.  Follows the bad guy into the basement where pretty young girls are being sold in an auction.  Of course his daughter is there, is the prize of the sale and Daddy buys her (don't ask how) only to get caught.  Bad guys prepare to kill Daddy but he is SUPER DADDY so he proceeds to kills off another dozen guys with guns without him getting even winged.  After he kills all but one bad guy he shoots him a couple of times to get him to say where is daughter has been taken.  Where?  Another actual line from the movie "There's a boat, on a quay."  And that's all the info Daddy needs, because this is Paris and after all, how many boats on how many quays can there be in Paris (I'm guessing several thousand on several hundred)?  In typically stupid fashion, Daddy kills another bad guy, runs outside and sees the limo carrying his daughter and proceeds to chase it for several miles through the streets of Paris.  Any cops around?  Don't be silly, of course not.  And how does he know that this particular limo is carrying his daughter?  Who cares, he knows this is the limo leaving the party (out of dozens) which has his daughter.

After more vehicular mayhem, Daddy jumps from a bridge onto the luxury yacht, proceeds to kills a dozen more bad guys without a scratch, then kills the middle eastern sheik who is holding a knife to his daughter's throat.

And they all live happily ever after!!!!!

On second thought, maybe this is the worst movie I've ever seen.  But I'm sure as hell not going to watch TAKEN or JUDGE DREDD again to find out.

Great movie. I haven't seen a Liam Neeson movie I haven't liked, and this one is no exception. Been trying to figure out an actor that would be a good Jack Reacher whenever Lee Child's books are finally made into movies. Think Liam Neeson may be a good choice...
just watched this last night on TV. was 1 of the best movies ever.have seen liam neeson in many movies, but was incredible!!! great actor.

I was working in Paris in 2007 at the American Embassy, and when I was leaving work one day during the summer...I happened to bump into Liam Neeson, and paid him a compliment on "Batman Begins".  He was very nice, and actually struck up a short conversation.  I asked him what he was doing here, and he said that he was working on a movie called...yep--"Taken".
  I remembered that about seven months later, when this movie premiered in France (I don't believe that it reached the States until almost a year later).  In many ways, the story has been redone in many different forms--Mel Gibson's "Ransom" in the '90s; I even believe there was a George C. Scott variation in the late 1970s.
  Lack of originality does not go hand-in-hand with lack of entertainment, however.  If you combine Luc Beeson's knack for high-adrenaline action with Neeson, who is a LONG human being (IMDB lists him at 6'5"--I think they're a couple of inches SHORT) who certainly hasn't been afraid of taking big dramas (Schindler's List) or over-the-top action (Darkman, of course)...and the mix ends up pretty good.
  Neeson pretty much carries the film.  Love Maggie Grace as the daughter Neeson's Bryan Mills wishes to establish a relationship with, Famke Janssen--looking slightly older, but still a knockout--as the ex-wife who wishes the ex-husband would go away...until the daughter gets kidnapped in Paris; Xander Berkeley as the richer, more stable second husband who GETS OUT OF THE WAY when Neeson's Brian Mills goes on the warpath; Leland Orser and Jon Gries as coworkers in Mills' former life...
  But this is Neeson's film from the start, and he gives many sides to Bryan--the father who never forgets his daughter's birthday or misses an opportunity for her to pursue her chance to sing, the estranged ex-husband, the "preventer" when working in a bodyguard team for a singer (nice quick turn there, Holly Valance), the badgered male when the daughter wants to go to Paris--and the mother browbeats him into signing off on it...and last but not least, the ex-covert operations operative that goes medevial when his daughter is kidnapped by white slavers in Paris.  The movie's catch phrase--the whole line that Neeson delivers leading up to the "I will find you, and I will kill you" line is, in many ways, the early 21st century equivalent to Clint Eastwood's "Do you feel lucky?  Well, do you...PUNK??!?" speech from "Dirty Harry".
  Sure, the premise isn't original; and the characterizations are sort of staid.  But Neeson carries this movie, both with his emotional input and his physical presence.  Combine it with Beeson's take on action in movies...and we end up with a pretty good ninety minutes.  Highly recommended.
Liam Neeson was outstanding in this film where is is searching for his daughter who was abducted by a white slavery ring in Europe.  The visuals are great and most enjoyable in the Blu-ray format.
The disc played but the DVD Box and disc itself were most definitely not in "very good" condition. The case was broken in multiple spots.

Liam Neeson gives a gripping performance as a former special ops, espionage James Bond type, whose daughter is kidnapped by French criminals who turn girls into prostitutes, or sell them to super-rich perverts.
His wife, who has married a rich guy, since they spit, waits in the wings while Neeson tries to recover their daughter caught in an extensive criminal enterprise.

This is an exceptional film. Enough action an emotion to satisfy anyone.

Parents, if you're tempted to allow your teenagers to travel on their own to Europe, watch Taken before you decide. Today's Europe is a far cry from the romantic picture that many Americans still imagine. Bad things can and do happen to naive teens arriving for an adventure.  Having visited France, the setting for Taken, several times in the past decade, I can say firsthand that this country has been inundated with emigres from eastern Europe, and not all of them are innocents in search of freedom. Organized crime has assumed a new face with new mobsters, and in some cases, the newcomers are more ruthless than the natives.

The plot of  Taken centers upon a former CIA agent Bryan Mills, portrayed by Liam Neeson, whose daughter is off on a European jaunt, only to be victimized by Albanians eager to sell her virginal charms to the highest bidder.  Film maker Luc Besson, whose rep was made by  such action thrillers as  La Femme Nikita, ramps up the tension by having the abduction take place during a phone call from father to daughter, during which he coaches her to feed him vital info about the thugs. When one of them picks up the cellphone, Mills warns them to release his daughter or face his considerable, professional wrath. Of course, they blow off his warning. But two days later, he's onto them, and never, ever lets go.

Neeson displays his physical side, literally mowing down anyone who stands in his way with an arsenal of awesome martial arts moves and laser-eyed shooting ability. Keep in mind that I normally abhor films with brutal scenes of torture and endless chase scenes. I've recently read a lot, however, about sex trafficking, and have to admit that I was rooting for Mills to turn up the electricity and take out those SOB's. Much of the action is totally implausible, but the crime is so heinous that I don't care. Neeson brings a knife edged, single minded, merciless sense of purpose to this role,  and while the daughter and her mother are mindless social twits, it's hard not to pull for him every hard-won, a** kicking step of the way.

The movie Taken was very good. The action sequences were very good and the acting was decent. The movie is about a retired guy named Bryan Mills(Liam Neeson) who's trying to retire. His daughter goes to France with her best friend and she gets kidnapped. I will not say anything more about the storyline of the movie. But  I would like to say this though. The movie is pretty disturbing once you find out what happened to his daughter and why. I won't spoil it in how it was disturbing but I would say that people ages 15+ could see this movie. But if younger viewers would want to see the movie, than I reccomend them watching it on a clearplay filtering system which would take out the sexual stuff and more disturbing violence.(for more info, go on clearplay.com), THank you for reading my review.

Most people love it and a few hate it and both sides have valid points.  Viewed purely as an action movie it does what it says on the tin!  If you want to start analysing it as if it was an art house film then, of course, you can find fault because clichs do abound.  First off there's the air-headed 17 year old daughter, Kim, doted on by the ex-CIA specialist killing machine played efficiently by Neeson, who's been cast aside by the blinkered, indulgent mother, played by Janssen, for the safer and much richer second husband, Xander Berkeley.  Next, Kim decides she wants to do the groupie thing with her equally air-headed mate and troll around Europe after a rock group.  Naturally, doting father, who knows the ways of the world, fiercely objects but dumb mum sees no problem with this - after all, you're only young once!

The girls reach Paris safely, the first stop on their tour, but fall foul to the most horrible of scams.  Enter the East European nasties!  This is the bit, of course, that plays in to the most profound of our prejudices about the yellow peril, going back to such pernicious heavies as Dracula himself; the peril from the east!  This time, though, it's not Transylvania getting the bad press but the Albanian mafia, trafficking young women for prostitution, and Kim and her mate fit the bill nicely.  Dad duly brushes the dust from his skill set and proceeds to track down the kidnappers killing anything and everything in his way, with apparent impunity.

So what's the problem?  The action is handled brilliantly and, whilst the inevitable fight scenes do stretch the boundaries of probability, the baddies well and truly get their just deserts.  Just think about this: if your daughter was snatched and sold into slavery to be the sex toy for some rich sheik and you were a CIA trained killing machine with powerful financial resources available to you would you let anything stand in your way to rescue her?  Of course not! So the premise is fine: the baddies have to come from somewhere so why not let Albania have its turn; there have been plenty of nasty Brits - think, Die hard?  And as for the many improbabilities - it's fiction for crying out loud: albeit fiction, which has, unfortunately, echoes of the sometimes, very unpleasant real world. Perhaps, some people need reminding of this.
Good. They should have stopped at the first one.
